name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—If the Senate is willing to be gracious, given the confusion over the placing of this due to it not being listed on the red, I seek leave to return to the matter of public importance.
Leave granted.
—I have already referred to the letter that proposes that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion. I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—
—I understand that an agreement has been reached between parties as to speaking times in this debate. I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—I thank the Senate for their consideration. Obviously, the Senate as a whole is of a view that this is an important matter which does need highlighting.
I rise to speak on this matter of public importance because I believe that the Senate needs to devote some time to this this afternoon. It is a vital issue to the future of native forests  of this country and indeed to the future of our nation overall—our economy as well as our environment.
Australia is a unique land. Our native forests, in particular, are an ecological wonder. Our forests range from tropical to temperate, from open dry woodland to closed and wet canopy. They are host to a variety of ecosystems, encompassing many of the world's most unique animals and plants. They are found over flat, riverine or escarpment areas from the southern most part of the country to the northern tip. What is particularly extraordinary is the diverse range of forest ecosystems between and within regions. This makes it all the more crucial that we should protect and care for our forests. If properly managed, they could provide a sound economic base for a truly sustainable timber industry and a strong and permanent environmental base for our nation.
However, successive governments have sold these forests to the woodchip industry. This industry to date has shown little regard for biodiversity, little regard for the diverse range of ecosystems—animals, plants and genetic base—and little regard for the interdependence of all these. It has little regard for water 
 quality issues or other users of forest areas other than woodchippers. The woodchipping industry does have a high regard for getting the maximum amount of corporate welfare from state and federal governments and views the chopping and shredding of the maximum number of forest areas very warmly.
When the evidence about this industry started to become well known in the public arena around five years ago, the  media took a considerable amount of interest and, to their credit, published a lot of information on various forest issues, including economic and biological arguments as well as the basic environmental aspects of the issue. This certainly scared the industry and governments who, when their actions were exposed, were left able to do little more than defend the indefensible.
It was a time of full-blown crisis for the industry and, somewhere out of the public relations and damage control spin, the Regional Forest Agreement process was born. This meant that—instead of the industry each year having to face another public relations disaster as a new round of export licences were approved, instead of continual revelations about the appalling process used to determine those licences, instead of all that—we would have a Regional Forest Agreement which would be signed for each general logging area and which would allegedly meet competing demands and allegedly be ecologically sustainable.
However, the process that we have seen so far has been characterised by a lack of transparency, by bureaucratic obfuscation and by allowing much more woodchipping than previously occurred—so much so that even industry groups are alarmed by the destruction of many areas of significance and its potential impact on long-term ecological sustainability as well as environmental sustainability. Time prevents me from listing all of the problems with the Regional Forest Agreements so far. I am sure there will be other senators who will add to that body of knowledge, but I would like to highlight a few examples which go to demonstrate why this is a matter of such public importance.
In Tasmania the Regional Forest Agreement, as it currently stands, will remove 39,000 hectares of provisional coupes from the register and then add 40,000 hectares more. In other words, another 1,000 hectares will be available for logging. The state undertook to publish, by 31 October last year, a description of the methods of calculating sustainable yield. This has not occurred. They have also not published, nor made publicly available, compliance audits of the Forest Practices Act or the code of reserve management. Nor have they developed and implemented a threatened species protection strategy.
In the East Gippsland area of Victoria, certain data on wood, which it is claimed is publicly available, is not provided at all by forest agencies and there are regular attempts to make the process as difficult as possible for people seeking information. These sorts of petty impediments distract from the real tragedy and the real area of great concern—that forests along the banks of heritage-listed rivers will be decimated, leading to shocking water quality consequences.
In Western Australia the process is so bad that the environment minister has promised, after the RFA is finished, that there will be further changes. Clearly, the RFA there will not be the last word, as was promised. More than 30,000 people sent in submissions to that process, yet the environment minister will not allow the release of the audit into those submissions until after the RFA has been signed. What exactly is being hidden? Perhaps the fact that 80 per cent of people in the state of Western Australia want no native forest logging and no woodchipping. Even the National Party in that state, and some Liberal Party branches, are expressing extreme disquiet with relation to government policy on RFAs, because the Western Australia forest process is in such a mess. The department which, at state level, is in charge of the negotiations in the RFA process—the Department of Conservation and Land Management—clearly has a vested financial interest in the outcome. The department has a clear interest in ensuring the maximum area is available to loggers.
The forthcoming Regional Forest Agreement legislation that is being considered in this parliament is a small bill of only a few pages, but it represents one of the biggest environmental issues to come before the Senate. It is an issue that most Australians feel very strongly about.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: in view of the fact that this legislation is before the parliament currently and there was a reference to the committee that I chair, I believe it is outside of standing orders to be making reference to that legislation or, in fact, be dealing with any issues pertaining to anything that might come out of the committee's report. I would like a clear ruling on that at the start of this debate.
—I do not uphold your point of order for two reasons. Firstly, there is a general debate before the chair on the issue of RFAs and forests. Senator Bartlett is clearly addressing that. Secondly, I understand the President would not have approved the MPI if it had been contrary to standing orders. Her advice is that it is appropriately before the chair and, consequently, Senator Bartlett is in order.
—I therefore want to ask a question with regard to this issue. I allowed Senator Bartlett to proceed until such time as he made reference to the legislation that is currently before us. That is my question to the chair. While we can have a general debate, is it in order to be actually raising issues pertaining directly to that legislation? He made particular reference to the fact that the bill contained eight clauses.
—He can talk about the subject of the bill. He cannot anticipate the bill. I will be listening closely to Senator Bartlett's comments but so far, overwhelmingly, I think his comments have been in line with standing orders.
—I can understand why the government may be apprehensive about the reality of that legislation being brought to the attention of the Australian people, because of the impact that it will have. 
I think I just said that it was a small bill, rather than it had eight clauses—because I was not aware of that off the top of my head, and it is not in my notes—but I am willing to be credited with that knowledge, as well.
The reason why that legislation is important—without talking specifically about the content—is its oversight of the entire Regional Forest Agreement process which is happening throughout Australia at the state level, and the impact it will have on the future of our native forests. That is why it is such a major environmental issue which this parliament obviously needs to consider, and consider very deeply. It is an issue that most Australians feel very strongly about and it deserves clearer and stronger highlighting and more thorough consideration—because the bill itself, as part of the overall Regional Forest Agreement process, is an attempt by the Commonwealth to abrogate its responsibility for forests back to the states.
Forest agreements are being put together at state level in those states that have vested short-term economic dependence on woodchip royalties. We have a system where so much public money is given to the native forest industry in government subsidies that it makes the plantation industry almost untenable. That is what is at risk of being enshrined. The bill will force massive job losses to occur in the timber industry, particularly in the small sawmilling sector, and will be responsible for an unprecedented level of native forest destruction.
Important safeguards that have been put in place by this parliament over many years, such as the Australian Heritage Commission Act, the Environmental Protection Act, the World Heritage Act and export controls, will not apply to vast regions of our most important forest areas under what is being proposed by the government. That is made doubly horrifying because of the sorts of agreements that have been agreed to already at state level and those agreements that are yet to be reached in other states. Those important safeguards that this parliament has seen fit to put in place to protect our environmental heritage will be voided for 20 years. This legislation upholds a process which is fatally 
 flawed, and it will destroy rather than protect our native forest areas.
The Democrats are determined to ensure that the public are made aware of the major threats posed to the survival of our forests by the Regional Forest Agreement process as it stands at present, because it is such a crucial issue to the very survival of our forests and the survival of communities and economies that depend upon those forests and on the long-term survival of a massive amount of biodiversity and genetic diversity in species which are also dependent on those forests. Those are all at risk now in this country. The Democrats believe it is crucial that that risk is highlighted to the Australian people and as much effort brought to bear to prevent the calamity that is before us from occurring.

name: Crane, Sen Winston
text:
—I rise to speak on this matter of public importance before us to hopefully put a few myths to bed. One of the interesting things about this debate is the endeavour by those opposite to try to shift the goal posts in regard to what was determined in the national forest policy statement and subsequent regional forest agreements.
I think it is most inappropriate that we are debating this here today when the legislation is before us and a Senate inquiry will be making recommendations in a report to be tabled in this parliament. In particular, I would say to Senator Bartlett that I think he has compromised his colleague Senator Woodley to an unacceptable and unfair degree. I think he should think very hard about bringing these types of debates on when the Senate inquiry is yet to report to the parliament.
Having said that, I want to deal with some of the problems. I got in touch with the clerks to find out what I could and could not use. A quote from Mr Pearce, who gave evidence to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, sums up the position of those people who want to keep shifting the goal posts and who do not accept Australia's responsibility. In answer to a question from Senator Brown, he said:
He does not like the answer he is getting. The point is there has been a long movement over this issue 
 of sustainability. I have noticed that when people like yourselves who argued for sustainable development 20 years ago discovered that in fact you can have a sustainable development arrangement in the forests whereby the needs of the environment are looked for and the forests are harvested on a sustainable basis, you have jumped ship on sustainable development and started trying to develop other definitions which mean, in effect, sustainable ecology, that you cannot do these things. You have done that, Senator, because you have discovered over time that the sustainable development thing which you argued for 10 or 15 years ago did not produce what you want, which is no industry at all in a good many areas of Australia. Although you are here arguing that about the forests today, you will be in other committees arguing about other industries in other areas of Australia on other occasions.
My definition of these things is that you strike a balance between all of the needs of our people, and they do require large areas of untouched natural forest, on your definition and mine, put aside and safeguarded for all generations in the future. I agree with that and our industry agrees with that, and it is the striking of the balance which is important there. But our people also need jobs and our people use timber and paper and timber products. They use more than they produce.
I repeat: they use more than they produce. He goes on:
Senator, and people in Australia who argue for the proposition that we should not touch our own forests but continue to use wood and paper products in the way that we are are simply arguing for ripping off other people's forests, and that is not a position which I believe is morally sustainable.
I think that is the crux of or one of the key issues in this debate. I wish to make the point that currently Australia is using 14 million cubic metres of our own timber a year and importing seven million cubic metres. Approximately a third of the timber we use for things such as the paper I am reading from, the pads I am writing on, et cetera, is imported from another country. I find that an untenable position.
I want to make a few points. Once the RFA is signed, the forest management plan will be prepared. The plan will be released for public comment and full assessment by the Environmental Protection Authority. You hear in debate from the other side that once the RFA is signed that is the end of the matter; it is not. Why don't we get told occasionally that 
 once an RFA is signed the states have to report to the Commonwealth minister? They have to report every year. These are the facts that need to be put on the table.
Further to this assessment, the EPA will be involved in two processes to ensure sustainable wood production. First, it will participate in an expert panel to verify the level of wood yield before the RFA is signed. Second, it will be represented on a task force to assess forest management and timber harvest levels before the next forest management plan is commenced. Once again, that absolutely destroys the oft repeated lie that the process is left uncontrolled.
Moving to the regional forest agreements, there are many stages involved in this. The first and one of more important stages is the Commonwealth-state agreement on deferred forest areas. The second state is a formal Commonwealth-state scoping agreement. The third stage is a CRA, a comprehensive regional assessment. The fourth stage is public consultation. The final stage is negotiation of a formal Regional Forest Agreement to be signed by the Commonwealth and appropriate state governments.
Some of the most important evidence that was given to the committee—and we do not have time to consider it today but I refer senators to it—was from the Deputy Premier of Tasmania, Paul Lennon, when he put a few things in perspective.
Western Australia gets a lot of mentions in this matter because of the current situation. We have what I consider to be a very unfair campaign, and it is being run on emotion and not on facts from the consultation process that has gone on and the various reports that have been done. I place on the public record that 39 reports have been released to the public since it started in Western Australia. Currently, another eight reports are being prepared and are to be released, I understand, in due course. That is a total of 47. This process has been inquired into to an extent that no other industry has been—whether it be on environmental, tourist or forest aspects or on the matter of shutting up land for wilderness protection. 
You may not like the outcomes, but to claim that there has not been a process of public consultation on forest management in Western Australia is just plain dishonest. I will run through some examples of the process: 1982, EPA review of karri forest; 1987, regional forest management plans; 1990, resources assessment inquiry; 1991, review of ecologically sustainable development; 1991, National Forest Policy Statement; 1992, draft forest management plan; 1993, appeals committee review of forest management plans; 1995, deferred forest assessment process with 500 public submissions.
The list continues: 1997, eight public meetings in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997-98, 122 meetings with organisations; 1996-98, nine meetings of Stakeholder Reference Group; 1996-97, five meetings with Noongar Action Group; 1997, nine public open days in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997, 10 public open days in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997, 10 community heritage workshops in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997-98, seven indigenous workshops throughout the south-west; 1997-98, 195 meetings with organisations; 1998, the inquiry which produced 30,000 public submissions. I think that accurately puts on the table the processes that have gone on in Western Australia.
This has not been something that has been restricted to this side of politics. When Labor governments were in power in Western Australia and in other states, they were part of the process—including the governments of Brian Burke, Carmen Lawrence, Peter Dowding. Richard Court's government has been involved and, prior to all of these, so was the government of the final days of Sir Charles Court and that of Mr O'Connor when he was Premier of Western Australia. So this process has been ongoing. I think it is about time people focused on the truth when they selectively criticise the process of the RFAs. I will leave it to my colleagues to deal with the others.
In the time remaining I quote Carmen Lawrence in 1990 when she was Premier. She said: 
One of the major achievements of the final Management Plans was the identification of areas to be included in conservation reserves. While creation of all of the reserves is still continuing, all areas identified for reservation are being managed for that purpose in the interim. When the reserve system has been completed there will have been a 340 per cent increase in the conservation estate of the South west that is an increase of some 550,000 hectares. Many of the reserves, such as the Shannon river basin, have been made into national parks.
That process has been going on in Western Australia for a long time. Finally, I quote Carmen Lawrence again:
. . . it is far better to use timber from well managed Australian forests, where every tree cut is regrown, than to lock up our own forests while plundering the forests of developing countries.
I put to the Senate that Democrats Senator Bartlett's matter of public importance, if ever implemented, will result in the plundering of other nations' forests. (Time expired)

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—At the outset I also want to express a concern about the fact that Senator Bartlett has raised this matter today. He may believe this is a matter of public importance, and no doubt this issue is, but Senator Bartlett is well aware, having attended at least for a short time the hearings of the Senate rural and regional affairs committee, that we have just completed three sessions of public inquiry. We have taken evidence on these very issues, and the committee is at this very time in the process of finalising its report to be tabled next week before the legislation is brought back into this Senate in the following week. I would have thought that in those circumstances Senator Bartlett may have held his fire a bit and enabled that process to be completed and then, if he wanted to address these issues, he could have done so through the debate on the legislation.
I also note that Senator Bartlett, having made his short address, has left the chamber. I have always taken the view when I have been involved in proposing a matter of public importance in this Senate that as a matter of courtesy the proposer should be prepared to sit and listen to the arguments put by other senators. I know senators have other commitments, but I believe that that course is appro 
 priate, particularly if you put forward the proposition as being one of such major public importance.
The next point I wish to make is that we do not accept the statement within the matter of public importance, namely, `the failure of the Regional Forests Agreement process to protect the remaining native forests of Australia.' Our view, which has been put on the record in the other place by the shadow minister, Mr Ferguson—and I do not want to transgress the standing orders by canvassing some of the issues that will arise when we debate the bill—is that the Regional Forest Agreement process is an appropriate process and is a process that by and large is working. That is not to say that there are not some problems. But the problems, in our view, are not necessarily problems with the rules that are set down within the process that is to be followed. Rather, it would appear from at least some of the evidence that has been presented to our committee that the problems are in the attitudes that are being adopted by various parties. It is a bit like a football game. If the teams are not playing the game properly, you do not turn around and blame the rules of the game.
In our view the Regional Forest Agreement process is the appropriate way forward. In order to appreciate the process we have to at least look at some of the background of how this process developed. Every member of this Senate—indeed, including those who were not here at the time—remembers the divisiveness, the bitterness, surrounding the forest industry debates, particularly in 1995 when this parliament was blockaded for the opening week or two of the parliament. That was the culmination of this divisiveness, this aggravation, this hostility that existed in respect of the management of Australia's forests for a number of years prior.
We had, on one hand, those who believed that native forests should never be logged. We had on the other side—I suppose, at the other end of the spectrum—some representatives of the timber industry who believed that it should be open slather and that you should be able to export as many woodchips as you liked. 
In order to overcome the impasse that existed as a result of the legitimate interests of conservationists and industry and also to overcome the myriad of constitutional problems—where, on the one hand, it is the states that own and manage the resource but it is the federal parliament, the federal government, that has increasingly used its powers to regulate forest management—we established, under the then Labor government, the RFA process. Of course the genesis of that process was the National Forest Policy Statement of 1992, a statement that ultimately was adopted by the current federal government, the Howard Liberal-National Party government. Therefore, it has bipartisan support at the federal level. It is also a statement and, subsequently, a process which has been adopted by every state government in this country. I will come back that process in the moment.
I want to take issue, particularly, with a statement Senator Bartlett made in his address that there should be no logging in native forests. What disturbs me is this approach that is adopted by Senator Bartlett and certainly by some interested groups involved in this debate that the only solution is their solution, and their solution is `no logging in native forests'. That is an attitude that is contrary to the National Forest Policy Statement and quite contrary to the RFA process, because, whilst the statement and the process recognise the fundamental importance of conservation values, of protecting of our native forests, particularly our old-growth forests, it also recognises that there is a place for forestry use on a commercial basis. Right through the statement you will see references to that because the statement is about a balance. It states:
The objectives and policy initiatives are underpinned by the following agreed approaches to forest management.
That includes:
. . . commercial uses of forests, including wood production, that are based on ecologically sustainable practises are appropriate and desirable activities.
It also states:
The governments also acknowledge that a variety of uses of public native forests is desirable, provid 
 ed those uses comply with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. The objective here is the management of public native forest so as to retain the full suite of forest values over time. The governments acknowledge, however, that some uses, including non-commercial uses, may inevitably compromise other values, such as tourism and recreation values, at least in the short term.
Further on in the statement in section 4(2), dealing with wood production and industry development, it states:
Sustainable economic use of native forests and plantations is one of the principal objectives of this statement. Wood production is a major commercial use of Australia's forests. It can be integrated with a range of other commercial and non-commercial uses, among them nature conservation, recreation, tourism and water catchment production. Ecologically sustainable management of native forests for wood production involves maintaining a permanent native forest estate while balancing these uses.
And I could go on. It is a very detailed statement, as honourable senators know. The point is that some people just do not accept that the principles that underpin the National Forest Policy Statement and the RFA process involve both recognition of conservation values and the application of resource security for the timber industry. Until they understand that, they are not going to come to this debate with clean hands, with an objective approach.
In his address, Senator Bartlett briefly canvassed some of the evidence that was put to the committee. There was, of course, evidence put to the committee which submitted that the RFA process has not been carried out appropriately in some states. That has also been put on the public record. There is currently a major debate going on within the Western Australian government about whether or not the RFA negotiated in that state is appropriate, whether or not the assessments have been properly made. There is also some debate with respect to the RFAs that have been negotiated and signed in Victoria.
I believe the central problem at the moment is the politicisation of this process by the current federal Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey. It seems that ever since Mr Tuckey was appointed to this portfolio following the last election we have had nothing but trouble and a reversion back to the bad old days when people were at each 
 other's throats in respect of this industry. Mr Tuckey, for blatant political reasons, has attacked the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government has negotiated one of the best, most environmentally friendly agreements on regional forest management ever in this country. The New South Wales government under Bob Carr has the most enviable record in terms of protecting our national estate, our national heritage, our environment and, particularly, our native forests.
Since the Carr government came to office it has declared a total of 151 new national parks and nature reserves, exceeding its original election commitment by more than 600 per cent. It has recently announced the most comprehensive forest decision in the state's history, with some 380,000 hectares of North Coast forests reserved. At the same time, it has also delivered unprecedented security to the timber industry and its workers; a package that has been endorsed by the industry, by conservation groups and, indeed, supported by the coalition parties in the New South Wales parliament.
But what has occurred at the federal level? Mr Tuckey, for blatant political purposes, refuses to provide the funding that is required under the agreement for exit assistance because he wants to play politics. He wants to play politics even with his own ideological colleagues in Western Australia on this issue. That is not the way to deal with this very important issue. The way to deal with it is for the parties in all of the states to get back to the principles that underpin the RFA process, that is, achieving both ecologically sustainable development and resource security, hand in hand with conservation of our great national heritage. It should be done under the process that was established and supported by all state and federal governments of both political persuasions. That is the way forward. We believe the process is working. There are some issues that need to be addressed. I have got no doubt that we will be able to deal with those when the legislation comes before the parliament soon. (Time expired)

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I feel somewhat frustrated because there is 
 only three minutes allocated to me to speak on this matter. I am also angry because we are seeing a process in this parliament whereby, without the knowledge of most Australians, we are facing legislation within two weeks which will hand across millions of hectares of what is left of the wild forests in this great nation of ours to the woodchippers. That is called the regional forest agreement. Behind that name is the lie that it has the support of the Australian people. Every opinion poll shows that that is not the case. It has the support of the big logging corporations, in particular the export woodchip corporations, and through them I submit it has the support of the major political parties.
The problem here is that we do not have an adequate debate, with an opposition on one side and a government on the other. Both the political parties are lining up to push through this legislation in the interests of those logging corporations against the 80 per cent of Australians who do not want this continuing and unnecessary destruction of not only the great wild forests that are left in this country but also the wildlife in them.
I have in my hands a picture which you cannot see, Mr Acting Deputy President, but which I can. When we look at that picture, which is in the rainforests of the Tarkine Wilderness in Tasmania where clear-felling takes place, what we see is a whole mountainside in flames where once the rainforest stood. It has been scalped. Every blade, every leaf, every living animal, every living entity in that forest has been totally and utterly destroyed. Members come in here and say that this is ecologically sustainable.
On the committee evidence that earlier members have averred, when I have asked representatives of the logging industry—not least the Deputy Premier of Tasmania—what a natural forest ecosystem is, with one exception, they have totally failed to provide an answer. When you ask, `What does sustainable mean?' again they cannot answer—or they won't. To be honest about it, you cannot be cutting, firebombing and then poisoning these forests to kill any grazing animals that come into them after they have been destroyed and call that ecologically sustainable. 
 That is a lie. Anybody in the street can tell you that that is a fabrication. Yet that lie is going to be incorporated into action for far more extensive destruction of these forests and the wildlife that goes with them, including world heritage value forests in this great country of ours under this legislation which has had far from adequate exposure to the public.
In Western Australia in particular at the moment the debate is raging. The opinion polls show that a growing proportion of people are horrified by the potential for legislation to lock up these forests. (Time expired)

name: Calvert, Sen Paul
text:
—I would like to reiterate what has been said by a couple of earlier speakers about the matter coming forward today when the bill is being debated. I am sure that both Senator Bartlett and, no doubt, Senator Brown will have plenty of opportunity to put their views on the table. I must say, although Senator Brown complains about the amount of time he has had here today, I think our chairman, Senator Crane, has been more than patient with Senator Brown at the three days of committee hearings; he has given him a lot more time than permanent members.
In any event, I do not think Senator Brown will ever agree with any process we come up with in this place. The track record goes back some 10 years. With any opportunity that has been put forward by whatever government happens to be in power federally or in the state, Senator Brown and his friends in the green movement pay lip-service initially and, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, then walk away from the process. I really query why the Democrats want to derail a process which is guaranteeing the protection of potentially vast amounts of Tasmanian wilderness and old growth forests and replace it with increased exploitation of wilderness and old growth forests in other countries.
I would be the first to admit that the issues surrounding the best conservation use of Tasmania's forests—and in this case I would like to refer to Tasmania because it has completed an RFA and, therefore, I think it is 
 appropriate to tell the chamber what has happened there—are both complex and difficult. One of the main difficulties that arises is ensuring that the economical harvesting of timber can continue to be carried out in a manner which does not threaten fragile ecosystems, particularly where they are unique; that future generations are able to continue to appreciate existing natural wilderness and that harvesting does not occur at a rate which is unsustainable in the long term. I believe the RFA process was commenced to ensure that these and other difficulties are overcome.
It is worth looking at the objectives of the RFA process. They come as a result of the national forest policy statement that the Federal Labor Party put down. They come, in Tasmania's case, after 28 or so inquiries over a period of 10 or more years, when a lot of emotional debate has gone on and a lot of small industries in Tasmania have gone to the wall. A lot of jobs have been lost, and further jobs will be lost if we cannot collectively come up with a process that meets the objectives.
The objectives of the RFA process included social, economic, environmental and heritage objectives. I will outline what they were. They were to manage the forests for a potentially expanding and value adding industry. It is very important that we have that value adding industry because it provides jobs for the people of Tasmania, and we certainly need them at the moment. They were to provide for sustainable high value species timbers, to maximise areas available for intensive management, to protect a comprehensive, adequate and representative sample of forest biodiversity, commonly known as the CAR reserves, to protect vulnerable, rare and endangered forest ecosystem biodiversity and to protect wilderness and old growth forests.
The final outcome as recommended in the agreement signed between the federal and Tasmanian governments has delivered outcomes which meet all these objectives—far beyond recognised national and international best practice reservation standards. For example, under the RFA, 40 per cent of Tasman 
 ia's land area will be classified as reserves, including 39 per cent of Tasmania's forests, 68 per cent of the old growth forests and 95 per cent of all wilderness. These percentages far exceed the JANIS guidelines set as goals at the commencement of the process.
The new Tasmanian Labor government is a very strong supporter of the RFA outcomes for Tasmania. The Deputy Premier himself came to Melbourne to give evidence and strongly support the Commonwealth RFA legislation. Since the process was started by the Keating Labor government I am surprised that some of my Tasmanian Labor colleagues have not been more vocal in their support for the process—not Senator O'Brien, I must admit, nor you, Senator Sherry. But for some reason one or two others have been rather quiet.
After all, the RFA is expected to have many benefits for Tasmania, for its people and for the protection of its forests. Those benefits include the development and launch of a widely supported forest industry growth plan, a significant increase in plantation establishment, hundreds of new jobs to be created, resource security resulting in millions of dollars being invested in Tasmania, guaranteed quality of sawlogs available to Tasmanian sawmill operators, world's best reservation standards met and exceeded, with some 95 per cent of Tasmania's high quality wilderness reserved, and social and economic outcomes given equal consideration with environmental and heritage objectives.
One of the major things that this regional forest agreement process does is to create certainty. Well, hopefully it will create certainty. The sorts of arguments we have heard and this matter being brought forward today do not provide any more certainty. It seems to me that all it will provide is more of the same argument that has gone on for the last 10 or 15 years. I guess that is what some of these people are all about, particularly in the Democrats' case. I think one of Senator Bartlett's former colleagues, Senator Bell, would  still be here in this parliament if it had not been for the ridiculous attitude the Democrats took towards some issues. Senator Bartlett may care to look at some of the 
 speeches Senator Bell made when he was in this place. I think Senator Bell, for a Democrat, was rather supportive of sustainable forestry development.
I take issue with what Senator Forshaw had to say about my colleague Mr Tuckey. Mr Tuckey, since he has come to this job—I know for a fact, from talking to some of the union representatives in Tasmania—has gained the respect of the CFMEU members. The statement on sustainable forest management in Tasmania put down by Mr Tuckey and Paul Lennon was welcomed by the industry in my state. I also believe that the action plan he intends to put in place and the commitments he has given to encourage downstream processing are all positive things that will help the industry and the people of Tasmania and create jobs. I reiterate that this motion today is inopportune. It has been put forward at the wrong time. I look forward to debating the matter further.

name: O'Brien, Sen Kerry
text:
—A great deal has been said about the fact that this debate occurs at a time when the legislation committee is considering this legislation, so I do not propose to add anything further on that point; it has all been said. But certain things occurred during the committee's deliberations, many of which are on the public record, which I believe it is appropriate I refer to today.
The motion we are discussing is the failure of the regional forest agreement process to protect the remaining native forests of Australia. That is one of the more misleading statements that I have ever seen put before this chamber in terms of our being asked to discuss it. The very process that is being pursued as the Labor Party contemplates the RFA process is to lead to renewable, sustainable forests for harvesting together with reserves of forests, not the removal of the native forests, as is suggested in this proposition.
The first and most important point to be made is the Australian people should not be misled that the RFA process is about removing native forests. It is about retaining native forests either protected from logging or guaranteed to be sustained in a renewable 
 form. It also contemplates the creation of plantations so that, in the future, timber for pulping purposes, for example, will substantially come from the hardwood plantations that are grown as a result of the RFA process. My recollection of the environment movement's views on the use of forests is that it was preferable to use plantations for timber purposes. We have to get to that point somehow. The RFA process, as the Labor Party would contemplate it, will indeed lead us to that process.
Senator Bartlett's comment that he anticipates that the RFA will hurt small sawmillers flies in the face of the attitude of some of the green supporters who attended the hearings that we conducted in Melbourne. I was interested in the evidence of the Victorian Association of Forest Industries, particularly with regard to downstream processing. I asked for them to send me more information, and Mr Graeme Gooding sent me this letter and reinforced my recollection of something that took place at the hearing. A passage from his letter states:
I found the whole Senate Inquiry quite astounding with most issues raised by those submitting to your group quite irrelevant.
He is referring to the greens. He goes on:
Some seemed to think it was another RAC Timber Inquiry rather than a review about legislation. In particular I found it amazing in our session that the greens applauded the likes of Judy Clark when she essentially advocated closing down the 50 or so viable small (hardwood) businesses in Victoria and replacing them with one or two huge (softwood) corporations. They then laughed when I noted that Demby's sawmill in Toolangi had more than tripled their employment from less than 10 to 30 people. I could not stop thinking about what I thought was a bizarre event—environmental ideologues advocated big business is better than small family companies. Afterwards I recalled two points of relevance:
1.	 A media report last year noted that Auspine's relatively large pine mill in Portland had doubled its output last year and increased employment by 5 people. Gary Demby's little mill had doubled its output and increased employment by over 20 people. Gary is one of eight hardwood sawmills in the Central Highlands we surveyed who have increased direct employment in total by 160 people by value adding. 

It is my recollection that, when that sort of evidence was given, there was an attempt from the audience to belittle the witnesses. There was giggling and laughing—indeed, someone was blowing a whistle when evidence they did not like was being presented. I suppose every group can have its people who misbehave. Unfortunately, there seemed to be an organised pattern of behaviour indicating disrespect for the evidence that was being given.
Senator Calvert has given evidence of the sort of material that we received in evidence, which I also think is generally publicly known, about the outcome of the RFA in Tasmania. Having gone through numerous inquiries into its timber industry, world heritage areas and logging practices—and I am sure it will go through a number of other inquiries as it follows the RFA process and, as far as is possible, perfect the operation of the timber industry—Tasmania starts with a world-class forestry industry in many respects but will end up with an even better one. At the end of the RFA process, assuming that the Senate gives approval to the process—and that is a matter which I do not propose to comment on now—it will have an even better industry. I would hazard to suggest that, at the end of that period, even more timber will be taken not from native forests but from plantations, and I suspect that plantations will increase as a result of the RFA process.
One of the problems we have in dealing with this sort of legislation and environment issues generally is the nature of environmental politics. I have been a long-time supporter of environmental issues, and I have supported the environment movement in relation to many issues they have taken up about the forestry industry. Indeed, the forestry industry now will say that some of their past practices were horrendous, were unsustainable and ought to have been changed, and they have recognised that those practices changed, in part, through the contribution of the environment movement. I put on record today that the environment movement has played an important part in correcting some of the problems in the forestry industry and some other environmental issues.
The problem we have is the environment movement has not become an issues movement but a party political movement. To sustain itself, it needs the big issues to attract voters. It needs the icon environment issue so that it can run around and attract supporters to vote for it at the next election. Unfortunately, if the issue is not there, it has to do something, and that something is manufacture the issue. Unfortunately, there is a strong element of manufacturing issues in the complaints being made about the RFA process.
I am not saying the process is perfect and I am not saying that there is no scope for improvement. What I am saying is that we have moved from the environment movement saying that we need more and more plantation timber, that pine plantations were bad and that we should have a sustainable forestry industry, and we will get to the point where parts of the environment movement will do anything possible to sabotage the industry, irrespective of the impact that will have on jobs in regional economies in Tasmania, parts of Victoria, parts of New South Wales and parts of Western Australia. I am not saying that every RFA will necessarily be good.
—How many jobs has it created in Tasmania?
—I listened to you peacefully, Senator Brown, so give me the same courtesy. In terms of each of those RFAs, the outcome of this legislation is as yet not determined. As I said before, I cannot make any comment without anticipating the debate on that legislation, which would be out of order. That debate is yet to be had. To have said in this debate that the RFAs fail to protect the remaining native forests of Australia is blatantly arrant nonsense and, as has been suggested, it has placed Senator Woodley, who is part of our committee, in a difficult position in relation to his position on the committee's report to the Senate. However, I noted that there was a difference of opinion between the Democrats earlier today on one of the votes. (Time expired)

name: McGauran, Sen Julian
text:
—I will take up directly what Senator O'Brien just alluded to. Senator Bartlett chose to speak for the Democrats today. He stated 
 that their policy was that the Democrats stand against the RFAs in total, which has totally compromised Senator Woodley. We on the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee know only too well that Senator Woodley would be quite split with Senator Bartlett on this issue. As far as I can gauge to this point, Senator Woodley has agreed with the processes and principles of the RFAs. But now we have to assume that the Democrats are against the processes and outcomes of all RFAs.
Senator Bartlett failed to put any alternative before the Senate. The Democrats have no policy, other than to be against the RFAs. We can only assume that Senator Bartlett and the Democrats want to take us back to the old system, which was no system at all. It was just a system of confrontation, and it was the very reason the RFA process and outcomes were produced. Prior to that, we had terrible confrontations. Senators would remember only too well the logging trucks that surrounded Parliament House. That was one of the most dramatic demonstrations. The greens who invaded the East Gippsland area created another dramatic confrontation. All of those confrontations bring instability and uncertainty to the industry. All of them produce great social unrest and conflict for the 6 o'clock news, but that, it seems, is what the Democrats want to take us back to. The truth is they now join the extreme greens. Many of them, if not most of them, came before the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee to give evidence. They also wanted the total abolition of the RFA. That is the bottom line.
The truth is that they really do not want any logging at all. That is the stance of Senator Brown, which does not surprise any of us, but it does surprise us when the Democrats want to take up that position. They seem to be taking the side of the environmental movement, which wants the total abolition of the industry regardless of the $2 billion trade deficit we have at the moment. Senator O'Brien and Senator Forshaw, who surprisingly made some good contributions to this MPI— 
—They are usually excellent. This time they were good.
—Senator Forshaw, you spoilt your contribution when you politicised it by attacking the minister. You felt you had to do that, but that was nothing compared to the submissions we received from the environmental movement when they came before the committee, particularly when we were in Melbourne. Never have I seen a movement marginalise themselves so much before a Senate committee. They were intransigent. They were exhibitionists. They exaggerated their case. They were unresearched and fanatical.
Senator Brown interjecting—
—They were all those things, Senator Brown. I will give just one example. One group before us was Environment Victoria Inc., as they call themselves. They were involved in the early part of the RFA process and negotiations in East Gippsland. They went to the point of comparing the process of the RFA to Nazism, but they just could not get their point through. Their point was ridiculous. That was the type of language they used and it totally marginalised them in the debate.
The truth is that they objected to the outcomes of the RFA, not the processes of it. If the processes fell completely their way, they would not be against RFAs. They objected to the outcome—an outcome that is based on some pretty sound principles, which it looks like they will never agree to. There are 11 national principles stated in the RFA as well as broad criteria for biodiversity. No criteria are broader than these: the protection of 90 per cent or more of high quality wilderness, and East Gippsland meets that criteria; a retention in reserves of at least 60 per cent of existing old growth, and East Gippsland meets that criteria; and a benchmark of 15 per cent of the pre-1750s distribution of each of the forest communities to be protected, and we meet that criteria and better it.
The truth is that, without the RFA process, without the RFA outcomes, we are going to go back to the bad old days of confrontation. That is what the Democrats want. Of course, 
 that is what Senator Brown wants. He loves to see himself on the 6 o'clock news. But it will bring down the industry and it will cause great social disharmony.
