name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—A little earlier in the day, when in 
 debate on item 19 of schedule 1, we spoke about some of the issues that arise in relation to the enrolment form, prescribed persons and the regulations that now, today, in draft form have at least been provided to the opposition and other interested senators. And, in relation to debate on this matter, I do stress that these particular regulations are very much in just a draft form.
For example, now that I have had an opportunity to look at them, I note the following in part 4 of the regulations dealing with electors who can attest a claim for enrolment:
11 For paragraph 98(2)(c) of the act:
(a) an elector is a prescribed class of electors if the elector is a person mentioned in schedule 3; and
(b) if no person mentioned in schedule 3 is available for the person making the claim, an elector is in a prescribed class of electors if the elector:
(1)	 is not related to the person making the claim by birth or marriage; and
(2)	 is approved by an Australian Electoral Officer or the DRO.
After that draft regulation appears a comment—one assumes, an AEC comment—and let me quote it:
The notion of a prescribed class involves the presumption that the membership is fixed by the regulations. There is an element of subdelegation in the provision that an officer can approve membership of the class. It would be better for this power to be given by the act.
Then we go on to `verification of identity', also in part 4. Let me quote from the draft regulations:
12(1) For subsection 98(2)(a) of the act, the identity of a person making a claim must be verified by at least one of the following original documents:
(a)	 documentary evidence of the applicant's identity.
Let me interpolate what is in the document as a comment in respect of the draft regulation `(a) documentary evidence of the applicant's identity'. The comment reads:
Your instructions refer to section 202B of the Tax Act. That section simply says that an application must be accompanied by documentary evidence of the applicant's identity. There is no definition of what may or may not be acceptable evidence, nothing is added here by referring to the Tax Act.
And so it goes on. Then we get down to `verification of Australian citizenship' in part 
 13 of the regulations, which I will quote. Part 13(2) states:
The person's Australian citizenship must be verified by any of the following:
(a)	 provision of:
	 (1)	 an Australian citizenship certificate; or
	 (2)	 an Australian passport; or
	 (3)	 an Electoral Commission enrolment application form given to the person by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs . . . 
Again, there is a comment in the document which reads:
I am not sure if this is what you want here. The form was not attached to the instructions. Is this a document with evidence of the person's citizenship given to the person when citizenship is granted?
We are being asked to agree with draft regulations that are in this form. What about schedule 3 of the draft regulations on electors who can attest claim for enrolment? There the comment reads:
There is a similar list in the statutory declarations regulations. Could that be adopted? A statutory declaration may well be needed with some urgency while an electoral enrolment is a more routine activity that is prescribed persons for statutory declaration should be more than enough for electoral enrolments.
This is the form that currently the draft regulations are in. I am not necessarily critical. I appreciate that obviously they have to go through this phase in terms of their development. But the point I made earlier today is that we had this legislation first introduced into the parliament in May of last year. We have had a long time, almost a year, for these regulations to be worked up and developed and, I think, provided in a more complete form than the form that was just received this morning from the minister. I do believe, Mr Temporary Chairman, that is a very substantive point for us to make as well as having to deal here with the substance of the issue.
There are major problems in relation to item 20—the proposals to insert parts 2A, 2B, 2C and 2D after subsection 98(2) of the act. There are difficulties in some cases with very genuine people with the verification of Australian citizenship. I really think in the circumstances, even with the AEC and the government having finally worked this matter 
 through in draft regulation form, that we do not have a position where this committee ought to be expected to sign on to these regulations. This is totally unacceptable. I think it would be a grave mistake for the committee to just blindly accept the government's proposal in relation to these quite significant changes to the Electoral Act.
I have said before that what is motivating this is simply paranoia on the part of the government—and I stress that. The government's view, belief, claims, if you like, that there is widespread electoral fraud have never been able to be justified. This is motivated by paranoia on the part of the government; it is not motivated by a desire to ensure that we have maximum integrity in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That is the problem.
As I have said before, this is going to cost an enormous amount of money for what is, at this stage still, a dog's breakfast of a proposal that is before the committee. Why should the committee be so courageous as to bite this one off? Why should we, given the stage of development of the regulations, accept what the government is proposing?
I question very seriously the government's motivation. I question very seriously the process that has got us up to this stage. I question very seriously the state of development of these regulations, even in their current draft form. I strongly advise the committee not to embrace them at this point. It is for that reason that the opposition will be opposing item 20.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—The regulations can only be put forward in draft form. As I have said previously, it is not normal when you have legislation being debated in the form of a bill to have the proposed regulations also before the Senate or the House. In fact, this is a bit like putting the cart before the horse, but we have done this in the interests of making available to the opposition and the other parties a full disclosure of what we are proposing. The reason we cannot have it in final form is that we still have to negotiate with the states, because we have a joint role situation.
—You could have had it in a more developed form than this. And you could have provided it a bit earlier, and you know it.
—We have just had a comment that you could not have it in a more developed form, and we have just had criticism from the opposition that this is in such a draft form that they do not want to sign off on it. You cannot have it both ways.
—I said it could be in a more developed form than this, and we could have had it a lot earlier than you have provided it.
—It is in as advanced a form as we could possibly have it for this debate. If we did have to put it off to get the consultation to the states and those agencies for which we are talking about where you can lodge an enrolment, then you would be waiting for another year.
—We have been waiting for a year already.
—We know why there was a delay, because the bill was not debated because an election came along. Then we had a new parliament, and then we had the Christmas break. There is no great shakes in saying that there has been this inordinate delay. We have had an election, a new parliament and the Christmas break. That is a substantial reason for any delay.
I would suggest these regulations are in sufficient form for the committee to make an informed decision. Once this bill is dealt with and this provision is passed, we will then go to the states and deal with the states in relation to the joint role provisions and those agencies to ensure that there is no problem; that you can, for instance, go to Centrelink or Australia Post to lodge your enrolment to vote. It is as simple as that. That is the situation, and nothing could be clearer.
What we have here is a proposal by the government that there should be some verification of identity for those people enrolling for the first time. What we are saying is that it is quite curious—in fact, more than curious; it is inappropriate—that you have a stricter requirement to open a bank account than you 
 do to get on the roll to vote. Gaining the right to vote is a very important right indeed, and we believe as a government there should be some scrutiny in that process. It is as simple as that. What I am saying is that there are adequate provisions in these regulations for the committee to form a very informed view. In any event, these regulations could be subject to disallowance. At the end of the day, the government has a sound proposal as to the scrutiny for the enrolment of new voters.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—The Democrats, having listened to the views put forward by the opposition and the minister, and while the minister put forward some reasoned views, are not convinced that this level of complication is required to be added to the act. We will also be voting against this section.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 20, stand as printed.
	 Question put.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—I move opposition consequential amendment No. 2 on sheet 1226:
(2)	 Clause 2, page 2 (line 4), omit "20,".
This amendment, of course, relates to the commencement dates.
—The commencement date, as I understand it, as a result of the previous vote, is consequential. The question is that the amendment moved by the opposition be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
—We now move to item 24. The question is that schedule 1, item 24 stand as printed.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—I was making the point a little earlier in relation to item 24 that the real concern is the reference to prescribed person. It is not, perhaps, as much a threshold issue as some of the others, but we have indicated very clearly our concerns there. I am disappointed that the committee does not share the opposition's concern in relation to the prescribed persons. I would suggest that it is worth all committee members apprising themselves of schedule 3 of the draft regulations: the electors who can 
 attest claim for enrolment. It is very limited, and I think it is going to cause a great deal of logistical difficulties in the real world.
This is the point that I particularly made to Senator Harradine, through the chair. This is going to cause problems for people, whether they be house-bound or whether they live in rural areas—where there are a whole range of reasons why they cannot easily access someone who fits one of the categories here. This is unnecessarily causing grief and difficulty to people who genuinely want to participate in the democratic process. I would say again to Senator Harradine, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that I hope he has cast his eye over this list that has now been made available in draft form. I hope he makes a close examination of it and, as I say, the logistical difficulties it is going to cause so many in the community.
That is the reason that the opposition has opposed item 19 and item 20, and now item 24. It is a serious issue, but one I think we have probably debated now at significant length. I do not want to delay the committee, but I also want to impress upon the committee and reinforce the strong arguments that I think we have mounted in relation to our concerns about prescribed persons.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, the government has proposed that, while you would have an increased requirement for identification, you would afford persons seeking to enrol to vote a greater opportunity to lodge their enrolment form. So you would have more outlets or more venues at which you could go to lodge your enrolment.
In the draft regulations which we circulated, we indicated that places that could take these enrolment form applications are approved agencies of the government of the states or territories. That could be quite wide. It could be the electoral commission offices in relation to those states or territories; ATSIC—which would cover the indigenous sector of the community; Australia Post; an Australian embassy or consulate overseas—which would cover people travelling overseas; Centrelink—which is widely distributed through the 
 country; any court of petty sessions, district courts, the Supreme Court; the electoral authority of a state or territory; a local government authority or a local shire office; or a migrant resource centre—for those people newly arrived in Australia.
We have opened up the places where you can lodge your application to enrol to vote. We think this is a very good move, notwithstanding that our previous proposal to strengthen the identification of the person enrolling to vote was lost. We believe that this is a good move because it increases the opportunity and the availability of places where a person can enrol to vote. The current situation is that you do that through the AEC.
The fate of the former provision—which I mentioned might have to be revisited—remains to be seen. But, for the present, the government maintains its proposal in relation to this matter and commends it to the committee.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 24, stand as printed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—I mentioned the prior vote during which there was a member of the government absent. The senator concerned has advised that he was in the courtyard and did not hear the bills ringing or see the light flashing. He was unaware of the division even though he was not a great distance from the chamber. I would ask that the vote on that be recommitted, because—
—Where is this senator?
—He is here now. Perhaps he could give an explanation to the committee.

name: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip
text:
—I do apologise for the inconvenience that I have undoubtedly caused the chamber. I did not hear the bells. I was in the courtyard with one former member and one present member of the House of Representatives. I had only been there for a few minutes. I went out of the building and must have been out of earshot of the bells. My secretary came 
 down, but it was too late by the time I came back in. I do apologise most profusely for what has been an embarrassing moment for me.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I ask you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to draw this matter to the attention of the President. There is a concern about the courtyard. The bells do not sound out there. It is frequented by members of parliament. We should see to it that, besides the flashing of the lights, the bells sound out there. Increasingly members of parliament are liable to fall into this situation. It is one that can be fixed. To ensure a positive outcome from this, I ask that the President look at that situation to see if it cannot be fixed.
—Senator Brown, I will convey your request to the President.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I think you would be aware that the opposition has consistently taken a view in relation to senators missing divisions, who are almost always coalition senators, I might add—and I think that is a fair statement, given the record—that we have time and again recommitted votes taken in committee and in the Senate. The problem is simple: I feel we have now reached the point where the goodwill of the opposition is being taken advantage of by the government.
I do not direct this directly at Senator Lightfoot. It just so happens that the Senator Lightfoot incident is the third one since the Senate has resumed this week. We had a senator missing a division earlier in the week in relation to a vote to extend a committee reference, and we have had two instances of senators missing divisions in the committee stage of this bill—Senator Lightfoot on this occasion, Senator Ian Macdonald on the previous occasion, and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Campbell, in the first instance I referred to.
There is no doubt that if Senator Lightfoot had attended the division the outcome of the vote would have been different. I accept that. The point I make is this: time and again the 
 opposition demonstrates its goodwill by recommitting votes and ensuring that the will of the electorate is reflected on the floor of the Senate as votes are taken. I make this as a very serious point to the government: at some point there has to be an effort made by the government to  lift its game.
The government cannot slack off on its whip arrangements or on ensuring discipline amongst coalition senators, knowing full well that it really does not matter because the good old opposition on this side of the chamber, because it takes a principled and proper approach to these sorts of issues, will always play ball and agree to recommit votes. That does appear to be a trend that is developing. I hope the minister at the table would agree that that is simply not on. You just cannot depend all the time on the opposition to dig the government out of a hole of its own creation.
I do not direct this particularly to Senator Lightfoot. I make that point. This is the most recent incident in a long line of failures on the part of the government to get its act into gear. That is not to say that on the very rare occasion opposition senators have not missed divisions and been in similar circumstances. But I tell you what: the numbers on missing divisions are overwhelmingly in favour of the government. There have literally been only a couple of instances since Labor lost government in 1996 when a vote has needed to be recommitted—only two that I can recall—because of an error by an opposition senator.
Government senators are doing this time and time again. If the government simply takes advantage of this by saying, `If we miss a key vote, what the hell does it matter, because the opposition will recommit the matter and we will get on with it,' that is not good enough. I think it is about time the government recognised that it is not good enough.
The government should also recognise the appalling example Senator Alston has set in this regard as the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. I suspect that is one of the reasons this has occurred. Senator Alston has made an absolute art form of missing divisions over the last couple of 
 years. As deputy leader, he is in a position in which he ought to be setting an example. If that is the example that is set, we have too many other senators following it, including recently another senior government office holder in the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. I make that point very seriously. I think it is a reasonable point that the opposition is entitled to see the government take a little more effort in ensuring discipline in relation to votes in this chamber.
The arguments that are presented in relation to the courtyard might be right. Maybe the bells do not ring in the courtyards, but there are lights in the courtyards. Senators are supposed to be wearing pagers. There are a range of mechanisms to ensure that we do not have this circumstance occur. I stress: I do not blame Senator Lightfoot, because he is the last in a great long line of government senators who have failed the test of coming to divisions, and it is senior government senators who have set such a bad example.
Of course, we have also nailed our colours to the mast on this, because we have said that we will do the honourable and proper thing. We will continue to do the honourable and proper thing, but I will tell you what: we are entitled to revisit this if our goodwill is just going to be continually exploited by the government in the way it has. Just because the opposition—and, for that matter, minor party senators and Senator Harradine—agree to recommitting votes it does not means that the processes and procedures of this place can be taken for granted. I hope that is a message that Senator Ellison as the responsible minister in the chamber at the moment and the Government Whip, who is on duty in the chamber at the moment, take on board seriously. I am now saying that the opposition will agree to recommit a vote that yet again has meant that a very important provision that is going to very significantly impact on the electoral processes in this country is going to be changed as a result of opposition goodwill. But we have set the benchmark in this. Do not take advantage of it. Do not exploit it, and do not take us for granted.

name: Calvert, Sen Paul
text:
—I can assure Senator Faulkner that I do 
 take this matter very seriously. I point out that this is the first time we have asked for a recommittal on a bill this session.
—This session, which is three days old.
—I am not going to make excuses for the other two people who missed divisions. It does so happen that I have taken this up with the Prime Minister's office, and the bells do not ring in his office either, which is where Senator Macdonald was when he missed a division. The beepers do not work there either. That is something we did not know before. So if you are having a visit to the Prime Minister's office some time, Senator Faulkner, and your beeper does not go off and you do not hear the bells, you will understand why.
—That will be a red-letter day—
—It is not likely to happen soon.
—I can assure you that the government takes this matter very seriously. In Senator Campbell's case it is the first division he has ever missed since he has been coming to this place. I also remind you, Senator Faulkner, that we have recommitted votes in the same manner as you have, notwithstanding the fact—
—How many?
—I will check. I know there were at least two occasions last year when there were serious matters—
—Two, as opposed to 22.
—That is not the point. The point I am making is that I hear what you say. I take the matter very seriously, as do all senators on this side. Senator Lightfoot has apologised, and I thank you for letting us recommit the vote.

name: O'Brien, Sen Kerry
text:
—I rise to indicate that, in response to Senator Brown's comments, Senator Faulkner made some comments about pagers. I have been in the courtyard and I have heard pagers go off. I have also heard bells from inside the building. But the fact of the matter is that 
 every senator is issued with a pager. I know that my office and Senator Calvert's office page senators for divisions. If the senator chooses not to carry the pager and as a result of that this chamber is then asked to recommit a vote, then we should understand that the basis for the recommittal is that the senator has refused to carry a pager.  	 I do accept that sometimes pagers do not go off. In fact I was at a meeting where mine did not work, and I had it checked. But that is the responsibility of the individual senator, because it is their lifeline with this chamber when they are conducting their affairs and performing their duties around this very large building.
I want to emphasise that I do not accept that being in the courtyard and not hearing the bells is a reasonable excuse. I would not accept that from one of my colleagues as a reasonable excuse, because I know that they are issued with a pager and I know that, barring a technical difficulty, they should be aware that there is a division, be able to read a message on their pager and attend the chamber in good time to vote. In response to some of the comments made and Senator Calvert's comments, I am sure that he has emphasised to his senators that they must wear their pagers, even in the Prime Minister's office.
—I have an indication from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate that he is willing to recommit the vote. That being the case, I put the question that schedule 1, item 20 stand as printed.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—You are correct in drawing to our attention the fact that my consequential amendment was successful. If we recommit it, I obviously will not proceed with it.
—Is leave granted to recommit?
Leave granted.
—The question is that opposition amendment No. 2 on sheet 1226 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the negative.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —While we are on this subject, I might say to the committee that I almost decided to not vote for the recommitted motion. I feel that it may be necessary to extend the nominated officers, positions or persons in the draft regulations, and I would be grateful if the minister would indicate to the committee that, prior to these regulations being made, suggestions that come from members of the parliament and others will be taken into account so as to extend the list of those who would be able to certify.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—I thank Senator Harradine for that contribution. I give an undertaking to this Senate that we will abide by the suggestion that he has made that if there are suggestions as to other persons who could fit the bill in relation to the draft regulations that we have circulated, we will certainly take that on board. I know that Senator Harradine has mentioned that in some remote areas you may have difficulty finding someone who might be able to fulfil that role of witnessing an enrolment. I am conscious of that, especially coming from a state like Western Australia which has vast remote areas.
The government put this forward as a draft regulation. There is an understanding that where you have a situation which might not be accommodated by the list here, that has to be rectified. After all, we are not about to disadvantage people in remote areas or areas where there is no access to the people listed. I might say that this is an extensive list, but we certainly will take on board suggestions in relation to this matter. I give that undertaking to Senator Harradine.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—by leave—I move Democrats amendments Nos 5 and 7 on sheet 1227:
(5)	 Schedule 1, after item 29, page 8 (after line 5), insert:
29A  After paragraph 133(1)(a)
	 Insert:
		 (aa)	 certify a copy of the party's constitution and make it available for public inspection under section 139; 

[section 133—party constitution to be publicly available]
(7)	 Schedule 1, page 9 (after line 27), after item 44, insert:
44A  At the end of section 314AB
	 Add:
	 (3)	 The first return under paragraph (1)(a) or (1)(b) after each election must include a copy of the registered political party's constitution that is current at the date of the return.

[section 314AB—party constitution to be provided after each election]
These are related amendments which my colleague and fellow traveller on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Senator Murray, moved when the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill went through this chamber, albeit in a slightly modified version. The purpose of these amendments is to place an onus upon political parties when lodging their annual returns immediately following elections to also lodge an up-to-date copy of their constitution, which would then be available for public inspection.
Political parties remain fairly nebulous institutions in our community and derive their chief source of legality from this Electoral Act that we are discussing today. As the rise and fall of the One Nation party has illustrated, the customs of political parties do not necessarily insulate against improper use being made of those parties or, as we have recently seen, the privileges that attach to such a status. Even getting a clear indication of the structure and manner of operation of some political parties is fairly difficult. Nowadays incorporated associations and trade unions must all lodge constitutions which generally are available for public scrutiny.
This amendment seeks to make political parties and their organisational structure more transparent. Given, as has also been widely publicised, some of those parties at least are able to potentially be the recipient of a significant amount of public funds, the Democrats believe that it is all the more appropriate that this fairly small measure should be incorporated as part of the act.
Already when political parties apply for registration under section 126(2)(f) of the act, 
 they have to provide a copy of the constitution of the party. But that is not made publicly available and there is no requirement to provide any updated version at any stage after the party has initially been registered. These amendments seek ensure that when or if the Electoral Commission determines that a political party's application for registration should be accepted and the party should be registered, the commissioner would certify a copy of the party's constitution and make it available for public inspection under section 139 of the act, which deals with inspection of the register of political parties.
To ensure that that is updated, the related amendment requires the party to put in an up-to-date version of their constitution with their first return to the commission after each federal election to ensure that the public is able to have access to an up-to-date version of that party's constitution in case they try to radically change their structure in the interim. It is basically about ensuring a bit more transparency in the organisational structure of Australia's political parties. The Democrats believe that that is something, particularly in light of recent public debate on this issue, that would be a positive move.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—There may be an element of merit in this proposal that the Democrats have moved by way of amendments. I think we do understand what the Democrats are trying to achieve here. I am not convinced about the proposal. I am not convinced that the administration of this would not be very cumbersome. I do not how it would work in practice.
I would say to Senator Bartlett that it seems to me that it would be worth looking at the merits of this proposal through the processes of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. If there is a case to be made in relation to it, then as part of the deliberations on the current reference to the committee of the 1998 federal election, we could look at it through that forum. I would be interested to hear the case as it might be mounted.
I am trying to say something positive about amendments that, at this stage, the opposition cannot see its way clear to support. I do say, 
 even though we will be opposing it, that it might have some merit. I genuinely believe it is better looked at in the cold, hard light of day through the mechanism I have suggested.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text: —The Greens support the Democrat amendments here. If you turn it around the other way, why should the constitutions of political parties, particularly political parties which are in receipt of public funding or potentially in receipt of public funding as a result of elections, not be open to scrutiny? One political party, One Nation, recently has had a lot of heartache over its own party constitution, with members publicly feeling aggrieved about it. It would be a healthy thing for the political parties involved to know that at each election the returns after the election will involve them lodging a copy of the party constitution, as it may have been amended in the intervening years, so that it is there for all to see—a good piece of public accountability and transparency. The Greens support this amendment.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I seek some clarification from the mover. On revised sheet 1227, are we dealing with amendments Nos 5 and 7 or are we only dealing with amendment No. 7?
—Numbers 5 and 7.
—If we are dealing with amendment No. 5, that, in effect, is to retain section 96A of the act.
—The main difference will be making it available for public inspection.
—I am sorry. The Democrats amendment No. 5 says, `Schedule 1, item 18, page 5 (lines 24 and 25), to be opposed.' My version—that is the government's proposal—says `Schedule 1, lines 24 and 25, item 18, section 96A, repeal the section.' Am I missing the point?
—No. I suspect you have sheet 1227, revised 2, or is it revised 1? It is probably an earlier version of the amendment sheet, I suspect.
—This doesn't have `revised 1' on it. So we have `revised 2', do we? Thank you.
—The old goalposts have gone walkabout.
—Yes, the goalposts have shifted a bit. I see that it is relevant to the point that was made. I might just mention, apropos of Senator Faulkner's comments, that this matter has been around for a while, as I recall. So far as I am concerned, I have had sufficient time to chew it over. I see no reason why this should be opposed. What is wrong with requiring a political party to lodge a copy of its constitution at the time it is going to make the returns seeking taxpayers' funding? I intend without further ado to support this amendment. I do hope the major parties, the Labor Party and the coalition—the Liberal Party and the National Party—see fit to support this or, if not, to give us a pretty good reason as to why this shouldn't be supported.
—Before I call the minister: Senator Bartlett, when you first introduced the amendments you wanted them to be taken together, but I think in view of some of the comment it may be better if we take them separately when I put the question.
—That is fine. We will just deal with this as moving amendment No. 5.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—The government has a view which is not dissimilar to that of the opposition. Might I say at the outset that I know from my own state that the Incorporation of Associations Act requires that any body which is incorporated under that act should have a constitution and that it has to be lodged with what was formerly the corporate affairs office. It is lodged there for public scrutiny and is available for inspection. I am hazarding a guess here, but I would assume that in all other states the situation would be much the same. Political parties are incorporated under such legislation. So there is, I would submit, in state legislation already a situation where a constitution of a political party is lodged with an agency and that it is subject to public scrutiny.
However, having said that, I don't take anything away from the spirit of the proposal 
 put forward by the Democrats. There would be some administrative burden to the AEC in this, although, I would concede, it would not be overly burdensome. But the suggestion of Senator Faulkner's is not a bad one. Perhaps the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters could have a look at this. It is something which we cannot see our way clear to support today but perhaps the committee could have a look at it and include it in its report. It has current terms of reference looking into the 1998 election, and this is something it could take up. But I do not think at this stage the government can see its way clear to supporting either of these proposals.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—I will not delay the Senate greatly. I realise the situation with the numbers, and I do welcome at least the indication of interest, if you like, from both the coalition and the ALP and the possibility of exploring this in the upcoming inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Nonetheless, I do think it is worth highlighting that, as Senator Harradine said, it is not that difficult a measure. The constitution is already provided to the Electoral Commission when a registration is first put in, so really the only extra work would be adding that to all the other details that are already required on the register, such as the name of the party and the name and address of the registered officer, et cetera.
I do not think that is overly onerous. I do not think that having one extra piece of paper added to the returns, that have to be put in every year in any case, would generate particularly enormous amounts of administrative work for the Electoral Commission, given the amount it is already required to do in assessing returns of political parties. So I do not believe it would be a major measure.
On Senator Ellison's point about the availability already of the constitutions in some states under incorporated associations law, I am not an expert on the political structure of every political party registered in the country partly because you cannot see where their constitutions are so you do not know, but I would hazard a guess that a number of parties are not incorporated in various states and I am 
 not sure they would be necessarily available in that regard. In any case, we will pursue this through the joint select committee. In the meantime, anyone who actually wants to see the Democrats' constitution at any stage should look on our web site. We do not need to wait for this amendment to go through to show people what our constitution is.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—One point I failed to mention earlier is the lack of compulsion in this, and that is something Senator Bartlett might want to consider in any future proposal. If there is to be compliance, there is no compulsion in your proposal. I just point that out by way of assistance.
—The question is that Democrat amendment No. 5 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the negative.
—The question is that Democrat amendment No. 7 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the negative.
—We now move to schedule 1, items 44 and 45.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—This is a very important part of this particular bill, and one which does deserve some close attention from the committee. Items 44 and 45 really represent another attempt by the coalition parties to weaken disclosure. Weakening disclosure and the disclosure provisions of the act are something that the coalition has consistently pursued now for at least 15 years.
We believe that these increases in electoral funding disclosure thresholds would allow for significant sums of money to go through without being disclosed, and we cannot support that. Even the AEC does not support these measures. I think they have been driven along here by the federal secretariat of the Liberal Party. In the AEC's submission to the Senate inquiry into this legislation, it said in respect of thresholds for reporting donations:
The AEC advised against such changes in a submission to the JSCEM inquiry into the conduct of the 1996 election. 

That is very important to note. During the Senate inquiry into this legislation, the head of funding and disclosure of the AEC conceded the following:
The way that a donor can make such a large donation without being disclosed is by donating up to the threshold to each state and territory branch of a political party. So, for a party that is organised nationally in every state and territory plus with a national secretariat, you are looking at nine separate identified parties, in effect, for disclosure purposes.
A donor can make separate donations to each of those parties. Because they are not aggregated across the party across Australia, only within each state and territory, they will not be disclosed. So . . . they could donate $4,999 a year to each state and territory branch of a political party and go undisclosed. That would add up to just short of $45,000.
He is right. That is what it is all about, and that is what could happen.
—Except when you've got only one branch.
—Senator Harradine, there is one of you, but I would ask that, in relation to these particular items—that is, items 44 and 45—you look at the possibility of manipulation by perhaps a major political party. I would not want to name one, but the obvious one would be the Liberal Party of Australia. I appreciate Senator Harradine's unique circumstances in relation to that, but this is a very important principle.
It is important to note also that the AEC conceded that there were a number of other ways in which donors could split their donations so they would not be disclosed. For example, each member of a family could donate separately or a family and a company could donate up to the disclosure limit.
The problem here is that the coalition parties simply do not like political disclosure. It is as simple as that. They have never supported it. Their use of the Greenfields Foundation rort does nothing to inspire any confidence at all in the arguments they have brought to bear in relation to these particular clauses. We are going to be pursuing further amendments in the Senate to try to close once and for all that Greenfields Foundation rort.
As far as the Labor Party is concerned, we have always advocated tight and transparent 
 funding and disclosure provisions. We are not going to allow items 44 and 45 to see the Liberal Party national secretariat fundamentally and very significantly undermine the integrity of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, because that is what these items do. These items are key provisions in this bill, and the Senate really has to stand up and be counted on this issue. We need to retain the integrity of the Electoral Act and ensure that those who donate to and support political parties have those donations disclosed. That is in this parliament's interest, and I would suggest to the committee that it is very much in the public interest.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I too am opposed to the proposed increase from $1,500 to $10,000 in subsection 305B(1) and from $1,500 to $5,000 in subsection 314AC(1). The matter has been canvassed by Senator Faulkner, but we all know that even the $1,500 can be circumvented. For example, an organisation could pay its members certain funds which are then to be paid to the particular political party, whether it be the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or any other party. For example, porn merchants could be organising their video outlets and individuals to pay certain moneys to a particular political party, each of those donations being $1,499. Eleven organisations or individuals could pay that and be reimbursed, and there is no way that could be tracked by the AEC.
This is the sort of situation that can arise even under the current provisions. You are never going to have complete transparency, and that is the point I am making. In particular, you will never have complete transparency in a situation where the party—whether it be the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or any individual party—does not want to be seen to be receiving donations from particular sources. What can be done about that, I do not know. Possibly nothing can be done about it, but let us at least keep the lower threshold that is currently in the legislation.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I agree with both the previous speakers. It is difficult to prevent people from usurping the spirit of the current laws which state that, if 
 you donate $1,500 or more, it must be disclosed. To raise that to $10,000 is to raise by six or eight times the ability of large amounts of money to be transferred by way of donations to the political parties without it being traced. It is when people go to some length to hide the fact that the donation is coming that I suspect political leverage is most wanted as an outcome by those donors. Therefore, there is the greatest need for those people to be under scrutiny.
I do not know why the government wants this change. I would be interested to hear in succinct terms from the minister why the government thinks keeping a longer list of donors who contributed $1,500 or more is more difficult than keeping a shorter list of those who contributed $10,000 or more. One cannot help but suspect that the government sees a very clear advantage in having more of its donors shielded from the glare of public scrutiny. If that is the case, that is not a good thing. If that is not the case, then why bring these amendments forward? It does not add up. They are not a good thing; they are going in the wrong direction. The Greens, like the previous speakers, totally oppose the government amendments.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—In relation to that last comment, these amounts have not been altered since, I believe, the 1992-93 financial year, so I would submit the effluxion of time has some relevance here. When these amounts were set, it was thought that there were obvious levels below which there should not be any disclosure and that, over time, those levels naturally would increase with the CPI, inflation and other things.
In relation to private donations to political parties, it is quite important because the government does not see that political parties should be entirely dependent on public funding. There are some who would say, `Let's rub out private funding entirely and just have it on public funding.' But if that were the case, you would then have parties, as I mentioned before, that would simply run in an election, have a percentage of the vote and collect their cheque. Other parties wanting to 
 do more would want to not only rely on public funding but also rely on their own resources in obtaining donations and donations in kind.
I think that all political parties have received private donations—quite properly so. There is perhaps a perception that this question of donation to a political party has some cloud over it. The legislation recognises that donations to political parties are a way of life. The question is the level at which you draw the line for disclosure purposes.
The government believes that, in view of the effluxion of time and the fact that there is a question of the amount by which you might deter people from making a donation if it were to be disclosed—for instance, $500 to $1,500 for an individual, and $1,500 to $10,000 and $1,500 to $5,000 for the organisations—that could well deter people from making a donation because they do not want to have the disclosure. Obviously, some people do not want to make their political allegiances public. I think that is a part of our system which is important. We have a secret ballot—no-one questions that. The country led the way in that.
But the situation is that the support of political parties is not something that everyone would wear on their sleeves, for obvious reasons. I would expect there would be supporters of the opposition who would not want to be readily identified as supporters of the opposition, for personal reasons or other reasons—and I respect that. But it is a question of the line you draw in relation to disclosure.
I can foreshadow that the opposition has some amendments which the government will be supporting, the ones dealing with associated entities. We support those because we do not want to see the system circumvented. We have indicated to the opposition that we will be supporting these amendments. There are some that we have a difficulty with due to technicalities, but that is purely the definition of a loan and a credit card. We will deal with them later. But, right now, the government would commend these amendments to the committee.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—This section of the legislation is of great concern to the Democrats. I don't think it would be blowing our own trumpet too much to say that the issue of disclosure of donations and openness in relation to transparency of funding and donations to political parties is something that the Democrats have pursued with some vigour for many years. Our concern goes back to my predecessor from Queensland, Senator Michael Macklin, who pursued these sorts of issues with great diligence over many years.
It is important to emphasise what we are discussing here in this part of the bill: we are not talking about rubbing out private donations or the ability for political parties to receive funds from private sources—not at all—in fact, I would quite like the Democrats to receive a lot more funds and donations than we do from private sources. I am quite happy to be open about that.
Why the Democrats have concerns with this part of the bill is that it is not about rubbing out private donations—far from it—it is about rubbing out an appropriate level of transparency and openness about private donations. That is something that I am quite sure all of us would agree is of great concern to the Australian public: that people have some ability to be aware of who is donating and who is providing funding—as long as the transparency is there. It is similar to senators and members having to individually declare our assets and have that publicly available or tabled. It is not a way of saying that we cannot have assets; it is a way of being open and upfront about what they are so that there is transparency in the system and some opportunity for public faith in the system.
As I have said a number of times in this debate, public faith in the system is seriously stretched in Australia at the moment. As a parliament, we do not want to be supporting measures that will further increase public cynicism or will lead to a decrease in public faith in the political and parliamentary process. The Democrats are opposed to the two sections of the bill that we are debating at the moment—again, just to make it clear to those multitudes listening to the debate. In parts of 
 the legislation currently, if a person in any one financial year makes gifts totalling $1,500 or more to any registered political party or the same state branch of a political party, they have to put in a return to the Electoral Commission.
What this measure seeks to do is change that to $10,000; that is, for a person now to be able to make a gift totalling $10,000 to the same registered political party or the same state branch. Of course, all of us here know that you can donate underneath the threshold to more than one branch of a political party and not be required to put in a return. So it is a significant leap. Whilst I take Senator Ellison's point about the effects of the CPI since these figures were first put in, we also have to look at the state of the world as it is now and the appropriate level of public expectation about what level of donations should be declared. I suggest that $10,000 is well and truly over and above that.
Similarly, the bill before us seeks to amend the act so that, instead of a party having to include particulars of where a sum amounting to more than $1,500 has come from, that amount will now move up to $5,000. Again, if this were to go through, once you factor in that a person or an organisation can donate to a number of different state branches of the one party plus the national level, you would have the ability to donate just under $5,000 to each state and territory branch plus, possibly, the national level. This would put you up around $40,000-odd. Over the course of an electoral cycle, a three-year period, you get up into well over $100,000 that can be donated to a political party as a whole, without there being any opportunity or requirement for that to be declared. In the view of the Democrats, that is well and truly over and above the level of transparency we should have in our Electoral Act.
—The question is that schedule 1, items 44 and 45, stand as printed.
Question resolved in the negative.
—We now move to Democrat amendment No. 8, that schedule 1, item 46, be opposed.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—The Democrats oppose schedule 1, item 46. We are here talking about a similar issue of principle. Item 46 of the legislation again relates to reporting thresholds, and it is another section of the bill that the Democrats oppose. Just to clarify again what this one particularly deals with, the section above section 314AC(2) of the act currently states that, if the sum of all the amounts received by or on behalf of the party from a person or organisation during a financial year is $1,500 or more, the return must include the particulars of that sum. But currently in the act, in calculating that sum, any amount less than $500 does not need to be counted.
What this part of the bill seeks to do is raise that amount of $500 to $1,500. So, basically, any amount less than $1,500 does not need to be counted in determining whether or not a contribution for a financial year is $1,500 or more. Again, from the Democrats point of view, this looks like an inappropriate weakening of transparency requirements of the legislation. Again, this is a measure that, for reasons similar to those that I have just outlined, the Senate should oppose.

This is obviously a very important issue. It is an issue that has arisen from a lot of public concern and many concerns raised in the parliament, particularly by me on behalf of the opposition in relation to what I believe has been a mechanism used by the government to subvert the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act.
What our amendments are about—the first three that have been accepted by the committee and these three—is simply this: we want 
 to end once and for all what we believe is the vehicle by which the Liberal Party has exploited any real or apparent loopholes in the Electoral Act. The vehicle that is being used, the Greenfields Foundation, has meant that one of the major political parties in this country, the  majority party in this coalition government, has been able to dodge full and transparent disclosure. I want to say this, being as generous as I can in the circumstances: the government did take some steps to address recommendation 10 of the March 1998 report of the AEC into funding and disclosure by broadening the investigative powers of the AEC in dealing with and determining whether or not an organisation is an associated entity.
We found out, as senators would know, during questioning of the Australian Electoral Commission at Senate estimates hearings last week, that the AEC recently utilised these powers for the first time to serve notice on the Greenfields Foundation on 15 January 1999. While those particular government amendments were sufficient for the purpose of broadening the investigative powers of the AEC in pursuing suspected associated entities, they have not gone far enough in relation to the crucial issue of closing the loophole in the legislation. That is what the opposition wants to do.
Let me explain to the committee what our amendments here are about. Firstly, they tighten the definition of `associated entity'. Secondly, they close the loophole in the event of the loan being given ultimately becoming a gift. Thirdly, they prevent loans from being received from anyone other than a registered financial institution unless certain information, such as terms and conditions of the loan, are disclosed. I might continue arguing this very strong case tomorrow.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the document. 

This is the final report of the Safety Review Committee which has the responsibility to ensure the safety of the operations at Lucas Heights. It is the final report because its responsibilities are being taken over by the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency and its councils and committees. The responsibility of this committee cannot be underestimated. Nuclear safety is an issue of paramount concern, and I have no reason to doubt the integrity or the qualifications or the commitment to safety or even the effectiveness of the committee in ensuring safety. But this report gives me no reason to have a lot of confidence either. One of the problems is the superficiality of much of the report. Whenever there is something of potential concern, it gets a glancing mention which raises more questions than answers. I will come to some of those concerns and the questions that come to mind in a moment.
The other problem is that the committee considered there were no matters arising in regard to the committee's functions B, C and D during the period of the report. These are the functions involving investigating and advising on matters which may have adverse consequences or safety implications. Even from the relative superficiality of the report, it is clear that there were matters that could well have been investigated. For example, there is the matter of the granting of temporary exemption from certain operating limits and conditions.
The report gives us no indication of which operating limits or conditions. Perhaps the minister could throw some light on this. Were these exemptions related to allowed levels of radiation exposure? What were the causes of the events which led to exemptions? Were the causes age related and do they have implications for the reactor surviving to the year 2005? Following these exemptions, the report tells us, the Nuclear Safety Bureau required ANSTO to provide data on the state of the reactor 24 hours after start-up. It would be nice to know that what that data said was okay.
Another issue worthy of investigation is the advice from the Nuclear Safety Bureau that, with foreseeable resource demands for the 
 replacement reactor project, the potential exists for resources to be diverted from HIFAR to the detriment of current high standards of reactor operations. When the Nuclear Safety Bureau starts flagging concerns like this, it is time to take notice. They draw attention to the loss of two senior staff, which they say represents a significant loss of managerial and technical expertise.
What this highlights is the issue of the skills base in Australia and the potential for difficulties in staffing the new reactor and the various monitoring bodies, especially when the new reactor might be running alongside the existing one for a period of time. It is good to see the Nuclear Safety Bureau being proactive in drawing attention to this problem, and I wonder if they have expanded on those concerns in the environmental impact statement on the new reactor.
Another issue arises in relation to the intermediate level liquid wastes. We are told liquid waste will be treated in a hot cell by a process of evaporation, de-ammoniation and solidification. We have been told this before. The question is: when will the process start? We are told the solid product may be suitable for processing into a ceramic form similar to synroc. May? This is typical of attitudes throughout the nuclear industry: create any amount of waste and work out what to do about it eventually. This is really not good enough.
Then there is the problem of the water in the spent fuel storage tubes. Again, it gets a mention in the report, but again the interesting thing is what is not said. How did the water get there? If it is rain water, then it must have been there for more than 10 years. What does that say about monitoring? How often are they checked and how? What about some genuinely independent monitoring? The International Atomic Energy Agency's monitoring is only to see if the seal is still in place. That is not safety monitoring. Is there any chance that corroded fuel elements will corrode further now that they are back in the ground? If water can get in through a faulty seal, one must wonder what can get out.
One area in which the Safety Review Committee seems to have been doing some 
 good work is in putting pressure on the industry in relation to worker safety. It is disappointing to note that there are still three radiation related injuries and five occasions on which radioactive materials were an accident factor. Thankfully, the doses involved were relatively small, but the fact is that any radiation accident is a serious worry. In the same way as we must work towards zero accidents, we must also work towards zero waste emissions. What guarantees can the minister give that the budget for capital works upgrade of waste management will be sufficient to achieve that end?
Finally, it is worth noting that what I see as deficiencies in the comprehensiveness of this report may be addressed to some extent by the strengthened community representation and reporting requirements which we achieved through amendments to the ARPANSA legislation. (Time expired)

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—I too rise to make some comments with respect to the annual report of the Safety Review Committee for 1997-98. As Senator Margetts has noted, this is the final report of the Safety Review Committee. That body has now been superseded by the establishment of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, colloquially referred to as ARPANSA. The establishment of ARPANSA is noted in the report, but for the period that this report covered the legislation had gone through the House of Representatives but was awaiting approval by the Senate. That is noted at pages 5 to 7 of the report.
I wish to make some comments about the establishment of ARPANSA. Like many, I was looking forward to the establishment of ARPANSA as setting the scene for an increased level of scrutiny and regulation of Australia's nuclear industry. As honourable senators are aware, I have a particular interest and involvement in this issue because I happen to reside in the Sutherland Shire, not far from the Lucas Heights reactor and, like all honourable members of parliament, what is close to home is often an issue that is dear to our hearts. Of course, the issues involved here are ones which affect all Australians. 
 Consequently, it is absolutely essential that any body established to oversee the operations of our nuclear industry, particularly the operations of ANSTO, is totally independent.
My initial enthusiasm for the establishment of ARPANSA, which filled in many of the gaps that existed in the regulatory system within Australia, has waned somewhat. It has waned, firstly, because the legislation, when it was brought to this Senate, was grossly inadequate. It was only because of the amendments that were put forward by the opposition parties and the Greens in this chamber that we ended up with an act which goes a long way to ensuring that improved system of regulation and improved system of scrutiny. Since then, however, I have become rather concerned about what the future holds.
At the recent Senate estimates committee on 8 February—the Community Affairs Legislation Committee estimates—representatives of ARPANSA and the Department of Health and Family Services appeared before the committee. In evidence to that committee it was indicated that the chief executive officer's position at ARPANSA has still not been filled on a permanent basis. A Dr John Loy is in an acting capacity.
What was more disturbing was that—following questions from myself to the departmental officer—it was revealed in evidence that a selection committee had been established within the department to draw up a short list of applicants to go to the minister, from which he would make a choice as to who the new chief executive would be. The most disturbing feature of all is that one of the three members of that committee drawing up that short list of applicants is the current head of ANSTO, Professor Helen Garnett.
I make no personal reflection upon Professor Helen Garnett's professionalism or qualifications but, as is said in the law, justice must not only be done, it must be seen to be done. If ARPANSA is to be an independent regulatory authority charged with the responsibility of overseeing the operations of ANSTO—in particular, the Lucas Heights reactor—then the head of ANSTO, the body to be regulated and scrutinised, should not be on the selection committee determining who should head up 
 this independent regulatory authority. I am amazed by that and I would urge the government to rethink its approach to filling this position. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: O'Chee, Sen Bill
text:
—In a well ordered world, the role of the state is to protect the individual. The role of the state is to ensure that mechanisms exist so that the weak and the vulnerable do not fall prey to others in society who would wish to take advantage of them. To this end, we have established in this country—and elsewhere in the Western world—elaborate mechanisms to protect the weak and vulnerable. The problem arises, however, that sometimes those systems become corrupted. Sometimes, organs of the state, instead of being a protection for the weak and the vulnerable, become instead mechanisms of oppression.
Tonight, in the first of two planned contributions in this chamber, I want to outline the circumstances by which one of those organs of the state, instead of protecting the weak and vulnerable people—as the intention was when it was established—became a mechanism to continue the oppression of the weak and the vulnerable. The organ to which I refer was the then Australian Securities Commission. The matter in question arose out of a failed fraudulent investment scheme in Queensland called Aust-Home Investments. It was a scheme which, at its height, conned hundreds of people into investing their funds, never to see them again. To this day, the promoters of this scheme have not been prosecuted. They have been allowed to go unscathed by the law, notwithstanding the fact that what they did constituted a criminal fraud.
I will outline how that situation arose. It was because of the manner in which investi 
 gators in the Australian Securities Commission handled, or mishandled, the investigation of the case. The circumstances were these. On 24 April 1991, the Australian Securities Commission commenced an investigation, under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act, into the affairs of Aust-Home Investments Ltd. On 27 and 30 May of that same year, they attended the premises of Aust-Home Investments and served statutory notices on 13 scheme companies—that is, companies associated with the principal entity, including all core entities. Certain documents were obtained as a result of those notices being served, but the ASC came to believe that other documents were not produced which should have been produced under those notices. Consequently, from 30 June until October 1991, the ASC conducted examinations of 21 persons related to that scheme. Some of the people who were examined were, in fact, scheme promoters, but many others who were examined were innocent victims of the fraud.
On 30 and 31 July 1991, and also on 6 August 1991, search warrants, pursuant to section 10 of the Crimes Act, were executed on offices which belonged to Aust-Home Investments at Astor Terrace in Brisbane and on 9 August warrants were executed on the residence of a scheme promoter. An enormous amount of information was obtained. How, then, can it be that, in spite of a substantial investigation, in spite of the fact that millions of dollars had disappeared, and in spite of the fact that millions of dollars of incorrect tax deductions had been claimed—innocently by the victims of the fraud but as a deliberate consequence on the part of the promoters—nobody has been prosecuted? The answer to this question lies in something called the derivative use immunity.
The problem was that the examinations were conducted under provisions of the Australian Securities Commission law contained in section 19 of its act, which enabled the investigators to compel people to answer questions. The problem was that evidence obtained under compulsion could not be used in a prosecution against the people who were the subject of the examination. So all of the 
 evidence obtained by the investigators in their examinations of the promoters was tainted evidence. It was flawed from the start. So, notwithstanding the fact that all of the information was available to the investigators of the Australian Securities Commission, once they had obtained all that information that showed what had happened to the money no prosecutions arose.
Over the years I have detailed some of the activities of the promoters of this scheme. I do not intend in this place at this time to rehash that, but honourable senators who are interested can find it easily in the Hansard. They will find, for example, that these promoters tried on subsequent dates in different places to perpetuate the same schemes in other states to con other innocent investors. One of the claims that the promoters used when they went to these other states and set up similar schemes was that it could not have been illegal to do what they had done because otherwise they would have been prosecuted by the Australian Securities Commission. A glib line, a line that tellingly assisted them in conning other innocent people.
But it was not just the promoters who were examined under section 19. Some innocent investors, for example, Mrs Margot Bunt in Queensland, were also examined. The emotional toll that this took on Mrs Bunt and others is incalculable. Many investors had their private assets frozen for years whilst the Australian Securities Commission continued with the fiction that they were ultimately going to prosecute the scheme promoters. However, no prosecutions arose. Eventually, a condensed report was prepared by the Australian Securities Commission, dated 19 October 1995. This report sought to explain why no prosecutions took place. Section 17 of that report at clause 8.1.5 says:
In the immediate case, it was believed that the immunity unavoidably affected the admissibility against the principal scheme promoter of all evidence obtained by the ASC on execution on 9 August 1991 of search warrants at 35 Astor Terrace office of the scheme and the promoter's residential address. This was because the sworn information relied upon by the ASC to support the granting of the subject warrants made a general reference to answers given during ASC examination pursuant to Section 19 of the ASC law on 6 August 1991 
 during the course of which privilege against self incrimination was claimed.
The report goes on to say:
In late January 1995, following consideration of advice received from DPP, it became apparent that all evidence obtained by the ASC subsequent to execution of the warrants, but which in any way was sought by the ASC in whole or partial reliance on the search warrant evidence may be inadmissible. In practical terms, it is believed that the immunity would also impact upon the admissibility on all other evidence obtained subsequent to the examination.
But the fact is that in 1991 the ASC knew of the impact of the derivative use immunity and in fact mention was made of it on 13 August 1991 in a submission to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, in which the ASC said that care had to be taken in framing an investigation to ensure that derivative use immunity did not allow criminals to get off the hook. Yet this is what happened, and the ASC continued with this fiction for four years to cover up what could at best be described as its own negligence. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard  an opinion from Hunt & Hunt Lawyers and an attachment thereto.
Leave granted.

OPINION RE:  MRS MARGOT BUNT
Mrs Bunt has consulted us over many months in relation to matters relating to Aust-Home Investments Limited and the investigation by the Australian Securities Commission (as it then was) of the affairs into that company in the early 1990s.
We have previously prepared a memorandum setting out a chronology of the events that occurred in that matter and append a copy of it.
What was clear at the time the memorandum was prepared and what remains clear today is that practices and procedures of the Australian Securities Commission (as it was then) were either not followed in the course of the investigation in relation to Aust-Home Investments Limited and associated companies and its directors or were disregarded. The consequence of the failure to follow the directions or of the disregarding of them is that the Australian Securities Commission was unable to bring any proceedings against the perpe 
 trator of the scheme which solicited millions of dollars of investor's funds which were lost.
That the Australian Securities Commission was aware of the relevant procedures is clear from the references to it in the attachment.
In clause 9.0.6 of the Condensed Report by the Australian Securities Commission under section 17 of the ASC Law dated 19 October 1995 said "notwithstanding the achievement of civil remedies, it is a fact that further ASC investigation did not culminate in criminal prosecution action. It is an unfortunate feature of this investigation that the impact of derivative use immunity was not fully identified until enquiries had reached a well advanced stage".
The Report went on to say, in 9.0.7:
"Whilst the immunity, since the amendment of subsection 68(3) of the ASC Law, currently does not affect evidence collected by the ASC, the experience nevertheless provides a salutary lesson to the ASC of the need to ensure the early identification of thresholds issues in relation to the immiscibility of evidence, prior continuing in investigation with an attendant expenditure of time resources and inconvenience to both witnesses and persons themselves the subject of investigation".
In 9.0.9, the report stated "whilst nevertheless conceding that the officers' subsequent actions had inadvertently attracted the derivative use immunity, it is not altogether certain that the officers could have acted differently and still ensure the efficient and expeditious procurement of evidence necessary to support the ASC's civil application".
Mrs Bunt is offended by the reference to the actions "inadvertently" attracting derivative use immunity. ASC was well aware of the matters at exactly the same time as the officers were carrying out the raids (see attachment for chronology).
Mrs Bunt's life has been devastated by the events surrounding the investigation, the freezing of assets, subsequent delays, the impact of the ASC's examination into the life of herself and her husband. As a result, her marriage has broken down and she is greatly concerned that she has lost not only the assets of herself and her husband but her marriage.
She believes she is strongly aggrieved and, upon consideration of the sequence of events, the attempted justification by the Commission of its actions as mere "inadvertence" does nothing to satisfy Mrs Bunt's anger or pain in the matters that have affected her life.
In the circumstances, an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the investigation and the subsequent report would appear to be justified.
