Mrs Bunt's concern is based upon the treatment she received from the investigators under ASC and the difficulties which ASC suffered in pursuing a criminal prosecution because of the way they carried out their investigations.
Mrs Bunt's concern is that the purported explanation of ASC does not accord with what one ought expect the ASC to say if it was acting consistently with a submission made jointly with DPP to the Joint Committee on Corporations & Securities and dated 13 August 1991.
The chronology is as follows:-
April 24 1991:
ASC intervened and commenced an investigation under Section 13 of the ASC law into the affairs of Aust-Home Investments Limited ("AHI").
May 27 & 30 1991
ASC officers attend AHI premises and served statutory notices on 13 Scheme Companies including all core entities. Certain documents were obtained as a result of those notices being served that ASC believed that there had been a failure to produce documents which should have been produced under those notices.
June 30—October 1991
ASC conducted examinations of 21 persons relative to the scheme.
July 30 and 31 1991 and August 6 1991
Search warrants pursuant to Section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914 (Commonwealth) were executed on office premises of AHI at 35 Astor Terrace, Brisbane and on August 9, 1991 upon the residence of a scheme promoter.
Subsequently no prosecutions were launched against the scheme promoter in respect of what appears to be breaches of the Corporations Law. The Section 17 Report of ASC dated 19 October 1995 said, at clause 8.1.5:-
"In the immediate case, it was believed that the immunity unavoidably affected the admissibility against the principal scheme promoter of all evidence obtained by the ASC on execution on 9 August 1991 of search warrants at 35 Astor Terrace office of the scheme and the promoter's residential address. This was because the sworn Information relied upon by the ASC to support the granting of the subject warrants made a general reference to answers given during ASC examination pursuant to Section 19 of the ASC law on 6 August 1991 during the course of which privilege against self incrimination was claimed."
In clause 8.1.6 of the Report, it claimed:-
"In late January 1995, following consideration of advice received from DPP, it became apparent that 
 all evidence obtained by the ASC subsequent to execution of the warrants, but which in any way was sought by the ASC in whole or partial reliance on the search warrant evidence may be inadmissible. In practical terms, it is believed that the immunity would also impact upon the admissibility on all other evidence obtained subsequent to the examination. . . .."
This attributes to the ASC a lack of knowledge, appreciation or understanding of the effect of what had been done in executing the warrants in August 1991 until DPP advice was received in January 1995.
And at Clause 9.0.7 it says:
"Whilst the immunity, since the amendment of Section 68(3) of the ASC law, currently does not affect evidence collected by the ASC, the experience nevertheless provides a salutary lesson to the ASC of the need to ensure the early identification of threshold issues in relation to the admissibility of evidence, prior to continuing an investigation with an attendant expenditure of time and resources and inconvenience to both witnesses and persons themselves the subject of investigation."
In clause 9.0.9 it further says:
"Whilst nevertheless conceding that the officers' subsequent actions had inadvertently attracted the derivative use immunity it is not altogether certain that the officers could have acted differently to ensure the efficient and expeditious procurement of evidence necessary to support the ASC's application.".
The question Mrs Bunt asks, in our opinion reasonably, is why the term "inadvertently" is used. The term implies accidental or unintended consequences. However, in the 13 August 1991 Submission to the Joint Committee on Corporations & Securities, it discusses in paragraph 2 the "practical and substantive difficulties arising out of the derivative use immunity." In clause 2.1 the Submission states:-
". . . .if an investigation is to proceed, a plan is prepared having regard to the means available to the ASC to gather information as evidence."
In Clause 2.2.2, the submission states:-". . . when the investigation plan is being prepared, the ASC cannot know whether it will pursue civil remedies or criminal prosecutions or both, nor will it be in a position to remedy the specific remedies or charges which will arise for consideration of a possible or likely defendant. The strategy which must be adopted, therefore, is that the Commission must have regard to the derivative use of immunity so as to minimise any prejudice to the possibility of either civil or criminal proceedings."
Why, then would the ASC be surprised by the advice in January 1995 of DPP as to the impact of 
 the derivative use immunity rule on the evidence obtained as a result of the execution of the warrants in the same month as the ASC was submitting it concern as to the impact of those warrants in its submission to the Joint Committee? It is perfectly clear that the ASC understood the problems involved. In this case, did the ASC proceed knowing the possible consequences and notwithstanding those consequences? Simply put, the statements made in paragraph 2 of the submission make it clear ASC knew in August 1991 the difficulties that existed by reason of the derivative use immunity rule and that, in recognition of the difficulty, it had put a procedure in place within ASC to take that into consideration. If it was aware of the consequences, why did it state in its Report to the Minister in clause 8.1.6 line 2 that "it became apparent. . . .", which conveys to the reader that this was a position which ASC did not appreciate or understand before that time? This would mean that the practice referred to in the Submission was not on this occasion followed. If that was true, Mrs Bunt is entitled to know why that was not done.
See Girvan Report 1.1 where demonstrates the existence of procedures which, when followed, avoided a scenario by which the persons suspected of offences were not orally examined.
Our client finds no adequate explanation has been given to her. We believe our client is entitled to a proper explanation and a reason as to why prosecutions have not been launched against the scheme promoter and the reasons for the ASC's actions in taking the steps it did.
Could you please obtain an adequate response for our client on this issue.

name: Allison, Sen Lyn
text:
asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, 23 June 1998:
(1) Does the Government agree that retention rates for isolated and remote students at 51 per cent and for boys at 44 per cent in Year 12 are unacceptably low.
(2) What are the social and economic implications of such low rates for these young people and the families and communities from which they come.
(3) Will the Government consider increasing the basic boarding allowance (BBA) of the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) scheme to its original intent of 55 per cent of the average boarding fee; if not, why not.
(4) Is the Government aware that the average boarding fee in 1997 was $6 783.
(5) Will the Government consider increasing the second home allowance of the AIC scheme to achieve parity with the BBA; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Government consider tapering the means tested additional boarding allowance of the AIC scheme up to the average boarding fee when the parents have nil or negative income with small increases applying as family incomes rise, as proposed by the Isolated Children's Parents' Association (ICPA); if not, why not.
(7) When will the Government adopt the recommendations of the ICPA to:
(a) recognise that families subject to an asset test for AUSTUDY should not also be subject to an assets test on their income earning assets;
(b) subject to appropriate substantiation, treat wages paid to students from their family's company, partnership or trust in the same way as earnings from an outside employer or sole trader partner; and
(c) provide adequately trained staff to assist people with queries surrounding the complexity of the AUSTUDY application form.
(8) Will the Government honour its 1996 election promise to raise the discount on farms and small business income earning assets from 50 per cent to 75 per cent; if not why not. 

(9) Will the government consider introducing a geographically-isolated tertiary students scheme, as proposed by ICPA; if not why not.
(10) (a) Will the Government consider providing an allowance to isolated parents who educate some 3 300 children at home; and
(b) how much do these parents save State and federal governments by virtue of their supervisory role.
(11) Will the Government consider the proposal by ICPA to provide recurrent funding of $1 000 for each isolated student enrolled in government and non-government boarding schools.
(12) (a) What is the low fee regional boarding schools and school term hostels which have been closed in the past twelve months; and
(b) how many places have been lost to these closures.
(13) What are the implications for isolated and remote students of these closures.

name: Kemp, Sen Rod
text:
—The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:
(1) The figures quoted are not rates of retention of secondary students to Year 12, but estimated Year 12 completion rates for remote students in respect of 1996. They appear in the National Report on Schooling in Australia 1996. Completion rates express the number of Year 12 completions (that is, Year 12 certificates issued by State education authorities) as a proportion of the estimated population that could attend Year 12 in a particular calendar year.
It is true that completion rates for remote students are lower than students from both urban areas and non-remote rural areas, and that rates for boys are lower than for girls. The Government agrees that it is desirable for more students to complete Year 12.
(2) The Government acknowledges that there are established links between educational achievement and employment outcomes. The Commonwealth's concern for the education of students living in rural and remote areas of Australia is based on a need to ensure their equitable access to quality education which will assist them to achieve outcomes and participation rates at least equal to students in urban areas. To assist these students, the Government provides a number of programs that offer additional support and help. For example, the Commonwealth provides $17.7 million to State and 
 Territory government and non government education authorities annually to help schools and students in rural and remote areas of Australia. The Country Areas Program assist parents, administrators, teachers and other members of the community to work cooperatively to improve the delivery of primary and secondary school educational services in rural and geographically isolated areas.
(3) The Government increased the basic boarding allowance from $2,500 to $2,900 in the 1996-97 Budget. This brought the basic boarding allowance up to 55% of the average boarding fee. The Government has undertaken to further increase the basic boarding allowance from $2,900 to $3,500 and index this amount in future years. It also undertook to increase the maximum amount that can be received under a combination of the basic boarding allowance and additional boarding allowance to $4,347.
(4) The Isolated Children's Parents' Association's (ICPA) method of deriving an average boarding fee is a simple average of fees charged by all boarding institutions and gives undue weight to the level of fees at expensive boarding schools which have relatively few AIC beneficiaries. The Department's calculations are derived from the fees charged by boarding institutions at which AIC recipients are actually enrolled and weighted accordingly.
(5) There is not necessarily a connection between the second home allowance and basic boarding allowance. The basic boarding allowance was increased in the 1996 Budget from $2 500 per year to $2 900 per year per student in line with the Government's specific 1996 election commitment to increase the basic boarding allowance to 55% of the average boarding allowance. No evidence has been presented of increased costs faced by recipients of the second home allowance. While the value of the basic boarding allowance and the second home allowance may previously have been aligned, the government's initial concern was to provide additional help to those families who needed to board their children in a non-family environment.
(6) Firstly, no family should receive more than their actual boarding fee outlay. Secondly, the ICPA proposal does not acknowledge that low income families have access to a higher level of Family Payment which may be used by families to meet boarding costs.
(7) (a) AUSTUDY was replaced on 1 July by the Youth Allowance for students under 25 years of age and AUSTUDY payment for those aged 25 and over. Both programs are the responsibility of the Minister for Family and Community Services. Means test rules remain in general the same, with the exception that students classed as independent are no longer subject to an actual means test. The ICPA proposes that families applying for student 
 assistance should not be subject to an assets test on their income earning assets. As with AUSTUDY, only fifty per cent of the net value of income earning assets that are also business assets is taken into account under the Youth Allowance family assets test. The assets test is complemented by the Family Actual Means Test (FAMT), which is a test of expenditure and savings. Expenditure that was tax deductible in the previous financial year because it was necessarily incurred in carrying on a business is excluded from the FAMT.
(7) (b) Under the Youth Allowance Family Actual Means Test up to $6,000 of income earned from independent employment by students in a family aged 16 and over may be excluded. "Independent employment" is employment engaged in by a person that is not provided by a member of the person's family or by a proprietary company, an unlisted public company, a partnership or trust in which the person, or a member of the person's family, has an interest.
The exclusion relates to income from independent employment because the Government is concerned to ensure that only bona fide income earning activities are recognised. The Government considered that, to maintain the integrity of the FAMT, income earned should be restricted to employment outside family business structures.
(7) (c) The matter of providing Centrelink staff to assist people to complete student assistance claim forms on a question by question basis is one that should be taken up with Centrelink. Centrelink staff are trained in all aspects of Youth Allowance administration including, of course, the Family Actual Means Test.
(8) Prior to the 1996 election the Coalition made an undertaking to consider raising the AUSTUDY assets test discount for farm and other business assets to 75%. Given the high cost of implementing this measure (estimated at some $18.5 million in a full year) and the fiscal restraints faced after the election, the Government was unable proceed with this undertaking. The Government was concerned also about making AUSTUDY and more recently Youth Allowance available to families with unencumbered business assets of up to $1.63 million, at a time when public expenditure is under close scrutiny.
The value of the family residence and up to two hectares of surrounding land is exempt from the Youth Allowance assets test. A 50% discount is available on the value of farm and other business assets, which means that in 1998, children become ineligible for Youth Allowance under the assets test only when the family has unencumbered assets of the value of $814,500 or more.
Since 1 July 1998, when the main form of financial assistance to full time students became the 
 Youth Allowance for students between the ages of 16 and 24 and the new Austudy payment for students 25 and over, policy responsibility for these schemes has rested with the Minister for Social Security. The Youth Allowance and the Austudy payment have retained the range of concessions available to rural students under AUSTUDY, including the concessions for farming families suffering drought or other exceptional circumstances, and those for families with two or more tertiary students living away from home to study.
(9) These issues were considered in the development of the Youth Allowance. The Government considered that access to post-secondary education, even for students living in non-isolated areas, often involves living away from home. Under the Youth Allowance eligible students who have to live away from home may be entitled to rent assistance.
(10) Introduction of an allowance to isolated parents would have considerable cost implications and need to be considered by the Government in the Budget context.
While State and Territory governments have the primary role in the provision of education to school aged children, the Commonwealth assists geographically isolated families with students studying by distance education through the payment of the AIC distance education allowance. This allowance is intended to contribute toward incidental costs associated with distance education study. In the 1996 Budget, the Government announced a substantial increase to the Correspondence Allowance from 1997 and specific funding to State and Territory Governments for the purposes of extending services to rural and remote schools, as well as for technological innovations in distance education delivery. These initiatives are viewed as the fairest and most efficient means of addressing the educational needs of geographically isolated students.
The Commonwealth provides general recurrent funding for government school systems and non-government schools and systems. Non-government schools are funded on a needs basis and placed in one of 12 funding categories. Given these differential rates of funding, and as it is not possible to identify which schools the students schooled at home could attend, it is not possible to determine the saving to the Commonwealth where students are supervised and schooled at home by their parents.
(11) Consideration of this proposal would need to be in the Budget context. It should be noted that hostels which provide accommodation for government and non-government students are eligible, under the Commonwealth Capital Grants Program, for grants from the Government Component and Non-Government Component respectively of the Program.  

Through its Schools Programs the Commonwealth provides recurrent funding for schools. Where boarding facilities are part of the school (ie. it is a boarding school) the assessment of the school's funding category through the Education Resources Index (ERI) takes boarding school costs into account. However, no ongoing recurrent funding is available for private hostels or other boarding arrangements.
The Commonwealth, through its General Recurrent Grants Program for schools, provides per capita assistance for government and non-government schools in respect of students attending those schools. This per capita funding assists schools with the recurrent costs of schooling like teaching and ancillary staff salaries, professional development of teachers, curriculum development, and school maintenance and general operation provisions. The current legislation governing the General Recurrent Grants Program does not envisage per capita payments to assist particular students with the costs of their schooling.
(12) The Department is aware of one non-government school approved for Commonwealth general recurrent grant funding that provided boarding facilities and which was located in a regional area outside the capital cities and other metropolitan centres, which closed in 1997. That school, which attracted funding at the category 9 level, reported 23 boarding students as at the 1997 schools census day. The Department does not maintain a specific, regular data collection in relation to low fee regional school term hostel closures and the number of places lost to these closures in the past twelve months.
(13) There are a number of schools offering boarding facilities in the area in which the closed school operated. These schools attract a comparable level of Commonwealth recurrent funding to that of the closed school. It would therefore be possible for students requiring boarding facilities to transfer to a similar environment. In line with its election commitment, the Government is providing short-term emergency funding to particular school term hostels in serious financial difficulty, while the Commonwealth sits down with the States to agree upon a significant long-term sustainable package for this sector.
